Posts.Title: New to the club

Posts.Content: A number of years ago I had a cardiac stress test at UPMC. The fee on the bill was $4500, the insurance paid $650 and they gladly accepted it as payment in full as a participating provider. There is a lot of fantasy land pricing involved in medical procedures, they should be willing to deal if you have cash. Sort of like when I was selling dress shirts and neckties in a department store. The price on the tag for a necktie might be $65, but 90% of the time there is a sale for at least 30-40% off and sometimes more, and the customer gets another 20% off for using their credit card. As a result, the average customer will spend $25 for item.

Posts.Title: mpMRI cost MAY be (much) lower than meets the eye - if a patient self-pays

Posts.Content: The typical standard of care isn't to give screening PSA tests at all to men in their 30's. Usually its not until 50 or above. 2.75 is definitely elevated for a man of your age, probably equivalent to my 4.2 at age 57--and I went straight to biopsy. Whether or not you want to go there or not is up to you, but its not outrageous that they want you in for the procedure.

Posts.Title: Age 39 PSA came back at 2.75

Posts.Content: Even though PSA stands for "Prostate specific antigen", that's really a misnomer. Gals have measurable PSA levels, even though they have no prostates and can never get pc. The level you have is one that a woman might expect to record- so minute, its essentially a zero.

Posts.Title: Age 39 PSA came back at 2.75

Posts.Content: Staging the cancer is the usual next step, because of your high PSA score. Bone scan is the usual plan of action to see if it has spread as Pc will usually metastasize there first. If you are all clear there, and you do surgery, that should clear your voiding issues. If you do radiation, they can do adjuvant hormone treatment which will also shrink your prostate.

Posts.Title: Newbies Head Spinning

Posts.Content: i think the key is to understand that there is more than 1 way to skin a cat, and appreciate the fact that they both can be right. in my case, the first doctor i went to stated that my own cancer was "intermediate" in aggressiveness. first thing i asked, i knew nothing and walked into the office that day expecting a clean bill of health. that turned out to be an erroneous characterization of it, and he disqualified himself. i had the same situation with the radial fx i'm dealing with now(the reason for the no caps). the first ortho man told me that surgery and plates and screws was a no-brainer. not really, a brace for 5 weeks and now pt is working out fine.

Posts.Content: Staging the cancer is the usual next step, because of your high PSA score. Bone scan is the usual plan of action to see if it has spread as Pc will usually metastasize there first. If you are all clear there, and you do surgery, that should clear your voiding issues. If you do radiation, they can do adjuvant hormone treatment which will also shrink your prostate.

Posts.Title: Finally time

Posts.Content: I'm 58 now, and I was 57 last winter when I was diagnosed. I had the PSA testing annually since I was 50, was referred over to the urologist when I was 51 when the PSA went from 2.5 to 3.5. They declined to do a biopsy at that point in time, the PSA was back down to 2.0 in 6 months and that was that. I don't know what my psa was in the intervening years, although it was taken every year, I didn't ask what it was as I wasn't asked to do anything about it. I'm ok with AS, my father had prostate cancer and took radiation for it in the 90's, he died of other causes about a dozen years after his dx.

Posts.Content: I had the biopsy last January, was diagnosed with pca, gleason 6 20% in one of twelve cores. My PSA has been up and down, the last one was 3.5 this month, it was 4.2 in November 2013. The first urologist I saw was anxious to do robotic surgery, I slow walked it a bit when it seemed like I was ripping food from his children's mouths by declining it and saw another urologist last spring. The UPMC doc said he was cool with surgery if I wanted it, but I could also be active surveillance. As a devout procrastinator with a wee cancer, I thought it was a better move. Anyhoo, when I had the biopsy last January, no drugs were offered and none were asked for. It was a tad annoying, but not terribly long and less annoying than the dentist, less than 15 minutes. The UPMC guy told me he'll give me valium before the procedure. Are there different ways of doing prostate biopsy that will make this next one a lot worse than what I did last year? Should I turn down the medication, I've tolerated benzies pretty well in the past but I don't like being overmedicated particularly in the morning when this is coming down.

Posts.Title: Newbies Head Spinning

Posts.Content: PSA stands for "prostate specific antigen", its a chemical that is released by only prostate cells. The test was originally designed for men who have already had prostatectomy. For those guys, the test should indicate a goose egg, they have no prostate, thus no prostate cells to create PSA. If they got a score , it means that cancerous prostate cells are creating PSA. The use of PSA for screening came afterwards. If you get a high or rapidly increasing score, the matter needs to be checked out further. BPH, prostatitis, other injury or trauma to the urinary tract can cause PSA scores to rise, sometimes dramatically. The idea of a screening PSA test result is to check it out if it looks out of sorts. Only a biopsy can definitlvely diagnose Prostate Cancer

Posts.Title: 38 years old very confused about whats going on

Posts.Content: I suspect your doctor will say you just have chronic prostatitis. Prostatitis can be very difficult to eradicate, and many men suffer with it for many years. The facts that your PSA level is sensitive to antibiotics, and you have had higher than normal amounts of white blood cells and pus in your urine all seems indicative of infection. Prostate cancer is quite rare for someone in their 30's, only 1 in 10,000 men get it at such a tender age. Most men actually diagnosed with pc are asymptomatic when they get the word, a high PSA test and/or a positive DRE is the sign. Newman said "What, me worry?" PC is a disease which is prevalent among an older population that often already has one foot in the grave. I remember driving my dad out to the urology office about 19 years ago for a PC appointment. He was 80 at that point and one of the young uns out there. If you combine that with fact that PC is often a slow mover, deferring treatment can often be a wise strategy. I met a man in a support group who was diagnosed at age 68 with Gleason 7 cancer and a PSA of 6. Posts.Content: Originally Posted by yxyxyx Prostate cancer is the solid “mass” inside large solid prostate “mass”. Can current imaging technology get clear image of prostate cancer and prostate with their clear “boundary”? I have the question because I never get exact size of my prostate cancer. What technology can measure exact size of the prostate cancer? Prostate cancer is usual many tumors, not just a single mass. That's why the standard treatments, radical prostatectomy and radiation protocols seek to remove or treat the entire organ. And that's one of the challenges that researchers are working on, focal therapies which will just treat and kill the tumor- which would theoretically mean less side effects for the patients.

Posts.Title: Radiation recovery time

Posts.Content: When you go in to see the doctor, he'll take a blood sample and re-do the PSA test, after that, he'll have you bend over and shove his finger up your keister to check your prostate. The doctor might give you a prescription for Cipro or other antibiotic, to see if that affects your PSA score and try to rule out Prostate Cancer. When I went with an elevated PSA, the urologist just moved to the next step and scheduled a prostate biopsy. The biopsy is the only way to definitively diagnose prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Is PC a chronic illness?

Posts.Content: By all means, get to urologist, you have a lot of disrupting symptoms from BPH/prostatitis which can be addressed medically or surgery. Its certainly possible you could have cancer with a rising PSA, but it is really unlikely that prostate cancer is causing your symptoms as it is only modestly elevated and not really indicative of stage 4 pc. It would seem to be possible that your increase in PSA is due to your other plumbing problems.

Posts.Title: Should I suggest a saturation biopsy...and how to prepare for the results

Posts.Content: There really isn't anything diet-wise that you can do that is proven to reduce the chance of a recurrence. However, a good died for healing and well as a return to regularity, would probably be an idea. No need for partcularly iron rich foods for the robotic surgery, as you will lose a minimum of blood. But add iron rich foods like spinach and beets, if they switch and do a bloody open procedure

Usually, even for the lowest-risk patients, which he appears to be, the AS protocols define that choice as best for those 65 and over.. The guidelines for active surveillance have been relaxed in the past few years. http://www.urology.jhu.edu/prostate/..._selection.php
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed husband - ?'s to ask Doc at our first appt?

Posts.Content: A "slightly enlarged" prostate is nothing, I wouldn't worry so much. As a man gets older and older, his prostate gets bigger and bigger. A 20 year old man has a prostate the size of a walnut, by the time he is 40 its the size of a golf ball, it becomes the size of a lemon when he reaches 60, and the size of a softball at age 80. That's your future, I wouldn't worry about it. There is a connection between self-abuse and the PSA test, you just want to avoid it for 3 days before the blood test as it does push up the score temporarily. But it doesn't have ill effects nor does it cause BPH or prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: slightly enlarged prostate at 34

Posts.Content: When you go in to see the doctor, he'll take a blood sample and re-do the PSA test, after that, he'll have you bend over and shove his finger up your keister to check your prostate. The doctor might give you a prescription for Cipro or other antibiotic, to see if that affects your PSA score and try to rule out Prostate Cancer. When I went with an elevated PSA, the urologist just moved to the next step and scheduled a prostate biopsy. The biopsy is the only way to definitively diagnose prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: slightly enlarged prostate at 34

Posts.Content: I think this is something that you really should give serious weight as to what the surgeon suggests. Its a lot more involved than a standard biopsy and a lot more expensive. I'd want a highly trained doctor advising it before agreeing to it, as it is very expensive and might not be able to be covered by insurance.
Posts.Title: Should I suggest a saturation biopsy...and how to prepare for the results

Posts.Content: Did you have a 2nd opinion on this, both on the pathology as well as the treatment plan? Prostate cancer cells can be tricky to diagnose, and a lot of patients ask for a 2nd opinion on the slides, it costs about $250. Did you ask the surgeon how much experience he has? As I'm sure you know, radical prostatectomy- whether done with robotic assistance or through open surgery, is one of the most challenging operations out there.

Posts.Title: (Hope this is okay) Mens Health did a PCa story and I am in it

Posts.Content: Based upon the information you provide, a PSA of 51 and Gleason 8 cancer, the Partin tables would indicate its really pretty unlikely that your cancer is organ confined. Even if you have surgery, you'll probably be lined up for adjunctive radiation after you're sufficiently healed from that. Hear what the doctors have to say about it, but if they determine your cancer is curable, you can probably expect a longer journey than most. As far as bike riding and sex before the PSA test, it wouldn't make enough of a change in your test to really change your prognosis in your case Partin "odds" based upon a PSA of 51 and Gleason 8 Organ confined: [1%(0%-4.5%)] Extraprostatic extension: [20.7%(3.1%-43%)] Seminal Vesicle Invasion: [48.5%(16.4%-78%)] Lymph Node Invasion: [29.8%(4.2%-67%)] http://urology.jhu.edu/support/partinTables.php

Posts.Title: Next-Generation Prostate Cancer Risk Calculator for Primary Care Physicians

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by AceVA I think we'd like to meet with: 1) urological oncologist 2) surgeon 3) focal therapy specialist 4) sex medicine specialist Focal therapy for prostate cancer isn't really that common or accepted. The reason why is that most usually, Prostate Cancer is usually manifested with numerous tumors, not just one or a few. Current imaging technology really doesn't allow that close of a look to see if the treatment got it all. In a few years, that is likely to change, as the science advances, just not yet.

Posts.Title: Cleveland Clinic Recommendations Please?

Posts.Content: There is a learning curve with any emerging technology in a constantly changing field like medicine. Not everyone gets up to speed at the same rate, this is a caveat for any kind of medical procedure particularly in its early days. If its at all possible, its probably better to have cutting edge procedures in major academic medical centers rather than be one of the first patients to have it at your community hospital. Experience counts, and with something like this which sounds highly complex, it probably counts more and for a longer period.

Posts.Title: It's that time of year again!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Not that I'm there yet but always get down 2 weeks before my 6 month PSA test. I know everyone is not the same but is there an average amount of time that HT works for the men taking it? What if anything are the options when your body no longer reacts to it and keeps PSA down?. Allen DOB..03/17/47 Gleason 7 (3+4) RALPH...Oct 2012 SR........Oct 2013.... Zero cub after radiation SR is a curative treatment, they don't perform it unless there is a pretty good chance it will work. Even if it doesn't, you stand a good chance of living for many, many years. Many prostate cancers are slow If it gets to the point that the cancer becomes hormone resistant, there are other new chemo and immunological treatments that can be done. The man playing the "lennie brisco" character from the Law & Order series played his entire run on the series under hormone treatment for pc before it became resistant and died. Considering you are about 70, under the worse case scenario you should probably be able to make it to 90 before you have to worry about hormone resistant pc, by that time you'll probably be dead of something else.

Posts.Title: Just wondering

Posts.Content: Based upon the information you provide, a PSA of 51 and Gleason 8 cancer, the Partin tables would indicate its really pretty unlikely that your cancer is organ confined. Even if you have surgery, you'll probably be lined up for adjunctive radiation after you're sufficiently healed from that. Hear what the doctors have to say about it, but if they determine your cancer is curable, you can probably expect a longer journey than most. As far as bike riding and sex before the PSA test, it wouldn't make enough of a change in your test to really change your prognosis in your case Partin "odds" based upon a PSA of 51 and Gleason 8 Organ confined: [1%(0%-4.5%)] Extraprostatic extension: [20.7%(3.1%-43%)] Seminal Vesicle Invasion: [48.5%(16.4%-78%)] Lymph Node Invasion: [29.8%(4.2%-67%)] http://urology.jhu.edu/support/partinTables.php

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddvh The Dr. recommends skull biopsy and will notify us further on how to proceed. Initially, Dr. gave 3 options, surgery, outside radiation or seed radiation, any suggestions? (Sorry, I don't know all the terminology yet) How likely is it that PC can spread to the skull? If so, what treatment would it be? He has an appt. tomorrow with the radiation doctor/center to discuss options, but I think it will be really basic due to the uncertainty of the skull spread. Does anyone suggest getting a second opinion? If so, any recommendations in the ATL area? Your father really needs the full workup on this. Yes, PC can indeed spread to the skull, but his PSA score (although quite elevated) doesn't seem quite high enough as pc usually spreads to adjacently before it spreads to such a distance location. The skull lesion could easily indicate a co-morbidity, something else that isn't pc related. Wait until the biopsy comes back, and the doctors weigh in, it sounds like your father has a complex medical condition or set of conditions

Posts.Title: New pc diagnosis & new to site

Posts.Content: Prostate Cancer at its early stage is almost always asymptomatic- no symptoms. Your psa scores indicate very small amounts, a prostate tumor which as metastasized and big enough to cause pain would almost undoubtably produce a lot more PSA. PC is very rare for a man of your age, prostatitis, however, is pretty common and can be very frustrating for the patient as well as the doctor.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed- My Father

Posts.Content: The paperwork for xtandi and zytiga says the medical indications for the drugs are for castrate resistant PC. They are both very expensive, I think you probably need to contact your insurance company and see if they will be covered. The clinical trial factor might change it a lot, really. If the money isn't a factor with your stepdad, he should decide which of these two oncologists he has the most faith in their judgment regarding this. Deciding exactly what to do about adjusting and managing doses of these cutting edge formulas, its beyond the pay grade of most people in the medical profession, but he should make a decision on which way to go based on his own gut instincts.

Posts.Title: Given a choice between docataxel or Zytiga...

Posts.Content: According to the ExoDX website, the test is for men 50+. Even though you got a bad score, it doesn't necessarily mean anything as you are significantly underneath the age bracket for the test. I think that you would need to know more about the test, whether because of biology it might give false positives for young guys. "ExoDx Prostate (IntelliScore) is a clinically validated, non-digital rectal exam (DRE) urine-based liquid biopsy test that predicts the presence of high-grade (Gleason score 7) prostate cancer for men 50 years of age and older with a PSA 2 – 10 mg/mL presenting for an initial biopsy. A “rule out” test, ExoDx Prostate (IntelliScore) is designed to more accurately predict whether a patient presenting for an initial biopsy does not have high-grade prostate cancer and, thus, could potentially avoid an initial biopsy and, instead, continue to be monitored. "

Posts.Title: Validity of ExoDX Prostate Intelliscore

Posts.Content: I'm not sure why the doctor thought it was a good idea to give someone this kind of news over the telephone on Friday evening, because there is nothing you can do about it until Monday anyhow. The short story is that the first step will be to determine if he has a curable case or not. Since its been determined "aggressive", the doctors will want to see if it has already spread, probably a bone scan will be ordered as that is where PC metastasizes to, first. If that comes back clear, then the two primary curative treatments are surgery and radiation. You can't get surgery until at least 6 weeks after the biopsy, so this is something you have to be patient with.

Posts.Title: My husband was diagnosed last night. This doesn't feel real. What should I do?

Posts.Content: Radical prostatectomy is done with the patient's head lower than the rest of his body. Further, it often takes 3-4 hours. That could put a lot of pressure on an aneurysm, depending on where its at. Further, if you have a diagnosed aneurysm, you might be on blood thinners, which also can complicate surgery. Radiation sounds like it could be a safer treatment for you.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA at 37 years old

Posts.Content: 164 is a very serious PSA score, especially if you are asymptomatic and not suffering from an infection. You'll definitely want to have a workup with a urologist, a number like that is often indicative of an advanced case of PC. The good news is that there are new treatments for prostate cancer all of the time, and you may well live for many more years even if the cancer isn't curable.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GW434 He recommended a biopsy (with propophol!). Based on my general health, weight, age, etc., he felt that although I fell into the 70% probability range, there was also a 30% chance that the biopsy would be negative. So, I'm really back where I started! UCLA wanted to perform "barnyard medicine" by doing the biopsy in the office with an injection of lidocaine (I freaked out about that). At least Cedars will put me under and I will avoid most anxiety. . Being put under for a prostate biopsy sounds like a bit much. Its a short procedure, less than 20 minutes, and I didn't find it painful with a local. If you are really anxious, they could probably offer you a short acting benzodiazepine. I declined valium when it was offered during my last 2 biopsies. I couldn't imagine doing this with a general anathesia.

Posts.Title: Which treatment is most common?

Posts.Content: The key statistic that you really need to look at with a surgeon is his experienced. If you have surgery, you want someone with at least 300-400 surgeries or more under their belt. Radical Prostatectomy , whether done in open fashion or with the robot, is one of the most technically challenging surgeries ordinarily done. And there is a learning curve. As far as the individual surgeon's rate of complications/cures, that's less important. In a group practice, the top surgeons often get the most difficult cases to work on. And those cases are often harder to get good results on.

Posts.Title: Just Received My Treatment Options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Joyf00 I'm praying for AS but not too sure doc will support it. He is 69 (closer to 70)...PSA was 4.5 April 2016 and 4.85 October 2016... was told at last appt when C bomb was dropped there was cancer in 1 of 12 cores and on a scale of 1-10 it was a 6 (we now know 6 isn't an awful thing thanks to the internet). Urologists are surgeons, and as such, are naturally biased in favor of surgery. BTW, that's the way it should be- I wouldn't want someone operating on me that didn't believe in efficacy of the treatment he was performing. A PSA score of less than 5 and Gleason 6 cancer is not really a medical emergency. Its probably not easy for you all, living out in the exurbs, but a 2nd opinion might be an option. You're in a good place here on the internet to hear what others have gone through, good luck on this.

Posts.Title: Newbie... Tomorrow my love meets with urologist for treatment options

Posts.Content: You always could apply and receive SSD or SSI on the basis of any severe condition that is disabling and expected to last more than a year or in your death. The difference, the change is that Stage IV PC has been added to the list of presumptive eligible diseases and conditions, where the diagnosis itself is enough to qualify you for it. Before this ruling, each case would have had to be looked at individually, before the Social Security claims people could rubber-stamp it as "Approved".

Posts.Title: Newbie to the forum

Posts.Content: The one thing you need to remember is to do your PSA tests all at the same lab. There are different assays, ways of doing it, depending on the lab, and it makes a difference of like 20%. The key thing to know about radical prostatectomy is that it is one of the most technically challenging surgeries commonly done. If you decide to have it- and I think you are a little quick on the trigger here- you want someone with at least 300 or more surgeries under the belt. There is a learning curve here. Right now, you probably should look to have a 2nd biopsy later on this year- a fair amount of time tumors with higher gleason are missed.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Joyf00 I'm praying for AS but not too sure doc will support it. He is 69 (closer to 70)...PSA was 4.5 April 2016 and 4.85 October 2016... was told at last appt when C bomb was dropped there was cancer in 1 of 12 cores and on a scale of 1-10 it was a 6 (we now know 6 isn't an awful thing thanks to the internet). Urologists are surgeons, and as such, are naturally biased in favor of surgery. BTW, that's the way it should be- I wouldn't want someone operating on me that didn't believe in efficacy of the treatment he was performing. A PSA score of less than 5 and Gleason 6 cancer is not really a medical emergency. Its probably not easy for you all, living out in the exurbs, but a 2nd opinion might be an option. You're in a good place here on the internet to hear what others have gone through, good luck on this.

Posts.Content: Even with metastatic PC and a high PSA, stepdad could easily live 10 years or more with current treatment protocols and new ones which hopefully more effective are being developed all the time. Different men respond differently to treatment- its really impossible to say how he will or for how long. As far as life insurance, probably not, his life expectancy isn't that long on the actuarial tables, but that doesn't mean there isn't hope. If he's under 65, he should certainly apply for Social Security disability and should get it if he's no longer working.

Posts.Title: Stepdad diagnosed with Aggressive Cancer but have questions

Posts.Content: The one thing you need to remember is to do your PSA tests all at the same lab. There are different assays, ways of doing it, depending on the lab, and it makes a difference of like 20%. The key thing to know about radical prostatectomy is that it is one of the most technically challenging surgeries commonly done. If you decide to have it- and I think you are a little quick on the trigger here- you want someone with at least 300 or more surgeries under the belt. There is a learning curve here. Right now, you probably should look to have a 2nd biopsy later on this year- a fair amount of time tumors with higher gleason are missed.

Posts.Title: Finding a good surgeon

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FrankB Thanks for the special treatment! What confounds the urologist is that the DRE was so normal and that I have no symptoms at all. With a PSA that high, he would expect burning, pain, difficulty urinating, etc. but I have none of that. As I mentioned, I only found this while checking on cholesterol and glucose! My last PSA was ten years ago and that was a 1.3. To add to this, I take finesteride for hair and from what I've read that can falsely bring down a reading, so it might otherwise be even higher? A PSA score of 28 is often asymptomatic. There have been folks with scores in thousands that have walked around, presumably for years, never knowing about it or suspecting a high PSA score or cancer until they had a test. The scale is "ng" which is very , very wee. Finesteride does reduce PSA scores, a dosage of 5 mg given for BPH reduces it by about half. Although I think they usually give less for hair growth.

Posts.Title: First PSA Test after RP

Posts.Content: PSA stands for "prostate specific antigen", its a chemical that is released by only prostate cells. The test was originally designed for men who have already had prostatectomy. For those guys, the test should indicate a goose egg, they have no prostate, thus no prostate cells to create PSA. If they got a score , it means that cancerous prostate cells are creating PSA. The use of PSA for screening came afterwards. If you get a high or rapidly increasing score, the matter needs to be checked out further. BPH, prostatitis, other injury or trauma to the urinary tract can cause PSA scores to rise, sometimes dramatically. The idea of a screening PSA test result is to check it out if it looks out of sorts. Only a biopsy can definitlvely diagnose Prostate Cancer

Posts.Title: social security and health issues

Posts.Content: I've had 3 biopsies, and was given different antibiotic regimens for the last 2 than with my first. (different doctors) There isn't one standard protocol. Both open and davinci surgery have the same degree of success when done by someone experienced in doing them. The main advantage to the DaVinci is a quicker recuperation by about a week or so. The open has the advantage of taking less time on the table and requiring less anesthesia. If you earn $5000 or more per week and need to get back to work right away, it might be worthwhile to travel for it. But as far as effectiveness, either method is equally effective with an experienced and talented surgeon.

The radiation guys do the best they can, but there will always been some radiation exposure to the lower digestive tract with prostate irradiation, and that does increase the chances of those cancers.

Posts.Title: My First Appointment With My Urologist

Posts.Content: The purpose of the bone scan and MRI is to stage his disease. If there are no metastases detected on the bone scan- they can go to curative treatments such as surgery and radiation. PC generally spreads first to the bones. If the disease is determined curable, they usually wait a minimum of 6-8 weeks to do surgery. They have to wait for the prostate to simmer down after being biopsied. There is sufficient time to get the tests done before surgery, considering the mandatory waiting time. Radical Prostatectomy, whether done open or robot assisted, is one of the most technically challenging operations commonly done nowadays. There is really a lot to be said for going to a top academic medical center like MD Anderson, particularly if you are looking for treatment for a complex case like your husbands sounds like it is. MDA is definitely a good choice.

Posts.Title: New diagnosis - Gleason 9, psa 20

Posts.Content: The purpose of the bone scan and MRI is to stage his disease. If there are no metastases detected on the bone scan- they can go to curative treatments such as surgery and radiation. PC generally spreads first to the bones. If the disease is determined curable, they usually wait a minimum of 6-8 weeks to do surgery. They have to wait for the prostate to simmer down after being biopsied. There is sufficient time to get the tests done before surgery, considering the mandatory waiting time. Radical Prostatectomy, whether done open or robot assisted, is one of the most technically challenging operations commonly done nowadays. There is really a lot to be said for going to a top academic medical center like MD Anderson, particularly if you are looking for treatment for a complex case like your husbands sounds like it is. MDA is definitely a good choice.

Posts.Title: Single Incision RALP outpatient

Posts.Content: The people that sell cyberknife technology are really interested in getting more prostate cancer business, a lot more people have prostate tumors than have brain tumors, and they have been able to get some academic medical centers to do cyberknife radiation on the prostate. It does save the patients time, they can complete cyberknifing within just 5 sessions instead of 40 or so, but it does have its own perils. If you think you want to do it, you'd probably want to be especially sure the doctor is really on the ball, as the radiation is a lot more powerful, and its not that much past experimental.

Posts.Content: Its really difficult to say. Its a statistically fact that African American men are diagnosed with pc more often than white guys. However, attributing it to their ethnicity is a real jump. I'd think we'd have to look at what the occurrence of PC is among blacks in other countries, take a look at black men who were raised by white people and compare them to the overall results before jumping to any conclusions. They tell me that asian men have a very low PC rate in Asia- but if they move here, they end up with a rate comparable to the rest of us. My guess is that it is more diet related than genetic.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TxMommy But we have another question on the cancer "escaping" ha ha or spreading. Is that why they are doing the cat and bone scans? Oh also on sending the biopsy out for a 2nd opinion. Im assuming I contact the place and do that but....no one In todays world seems to be in a rush. I know that obtaining a 2nd opinion is WISE but I worry that we could be waiting to long. I hope that makes sense. what is the typical time frame that they take to look at the biopsy? etc. That's exactly right, bone scans and CT's are done to stage the cancer. If it has already spread, it puts surgery off the table. The good news is that there is a good chance that it hasn't yet. A cancer which has already spread is more likely to produce a lot higher PSA score than a 12. If the husband is going to go into surgery, the earliest it can be done is 6 weeks after the biopsy.

Posts.Title: Advice. Thoughts. Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer at 52 Gleason Score of 6,7 and 8..

Posts.Content: The key indicator right now of your prognosis and whether you'll need further treatment down the line is the pathology report. Biopsies only view a small amount of the prostate. Once the surgeon removes it, it get wrapped up and shipped to the path lab to be sliced and diced. Your doctor will have a better idea of your gleason score , positive or negative margins, amount of disease, etc., once he sees the report on your total prostate.

Posts.Content: Sloan Kettering is a highly rated facility, its certainly a worthy choice for a 2nd opinion on your case. Posts.Title: Pet ct type for mets Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mark524 In July 2017 I had a biopsy that revealed a 3+3 (one core 20% and another 30%). Fast forward to August 2018 and my second biopsy revealed nothing at all (both 12 core biopsies). I posed the question to my urologist what next and I was told active surveillance as usual - another blood test in 6 months and biopsy in a year. Has anyone else had similar results on their second biopsy? If so did you still get another in a year if the PSA did not go up? I know if they found something the first time it didn't just go away but I am leaning towards another biopsy but if it turns out two in a row show nothing I am not sure if I should keep getting them. I know better safe than sorry but it is a bit of an invasive procedure with and infection risk. Your similar enough to mine, and I got a 3rd biopsy a year after my 2nd one which was negative. Since your PSA is only moderately elevated, you might be able to go for an MRI instead. Listen to your doctor on this. Its certainly a good sign to have a negative 2nd biopsy.

Posts.Title: Percentage #'s On Cores - How Important Is That?

Posts.Content: Although there is a good chance that your friend's disease has recurred, the doctor really needs to determine the rate its progressing- the increase in PSA- before they can determine what the appropriate answer should be. If the doubling time for PSA is long enough, and/or your friends age and co-morbidities are high enough, he might avoid any further treatment.

Maybe not that worried, if its not growing that rapidly, you may have many years left before it gets out of control. Further, there are treatments and strategies to keep it in check, even if the PC becomes more aggressive.

Posts.Content: MRI imaging has a more prominent place in active surveillance than it did just a few years ago. Its a lot less invasive that the urologist shoving a cutting instrument into your keister for a biopsy, so its also a lot less likely to have side effects. I don't think you've mentioned where you're at, but if you're at an academic medical center, going for the MRI immediately instead of another biopsy at their suggestion makes pretty good sense.

Posts.Title: 3t mri ?

Posts.Content: when someone has Prostate Cancer, they just don't have a single tumor, but instead many small tumors. That's the real difficulty right there with focal treatment, getting them all. Dr. Sperling says on his website he really gets a clear pic of the prostate to identify all of the tumors. I don't know if he can or can't, but its a really difficult task as a lot of tumors can be pretty tiny or hidden

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer Please help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jess4566 (based on the free psa that is still in your system that wasn't, and can't be, removed.) PSA scores are not specific to cancer, but those who do have successful radical surgery do get undetectable "0" scores. The PSA in the blood stream dissipates within a few weeks if no more is being produced by the prostate. Your father's PSA score will fall after treatment, but not to zero since he's getting a focal treatment. Non-cancerous prostate cells produce it too.

Posts.Title: How long after surgery can I travel?

Posts.Content: A PSA score of 60 is extremely likely to be cancer. But mistakes are sometimes made, re-checking it is prudent. The biopsy will be the clue as to how aggressive the cancer is. Pathologists will look at the cells as give them a gleason grade. If its cancer, they'll give him bone scans and CT scans, see if its localized. If prostate cancer is localized, it definitely curable. If it isn't curable, it can still be treated successfully for many years.

Posts.Title: Proscar for Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind After the Orchidectomy, there is probably no need for the Casodex (bicalutimide) There is no longer any testosterone to block and Casodex has a long side-effect list...... Factually not true. Orchiectomy severely reduces the amount of testosterone, but it doesn't eliminate it. Smaller amounts of testosterone are also produced by the adrenals. Whether or not this would need to be blocked, that answer is different for different patients.
Posts.Title: Surgical Castration done, Chemo starting soon, is Calutamide needed?

Posts.Content: Certainly a lot longer than what I experienced after any of my biopsies. I wouldn't panic over it, but I would give a call to the doctor next Monday if it doesn't stop and definitely mention it. For bleeding to continue for 2 weeks after being poked a few times with a needle is pretty rare.

Posts.Title: First time posting, cancer at 48

Posts.Content: Good luck to your father. There are good reasons to be hopeful, even though he has a tough diagnosis. Men can last many years, continue to work- although that probably isn't your dad because of his age, and hormone treatment can be effective for a decade or longer. After that, there are new treatments constantly being developed for hormone resistant PC. As far as his sciatic pain, who knows? Prostate cancer doesn't exempt men from other ailments that he can have concurrently.

Posts.Title: MRI results and a ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Try to stay optimistic. While cure is likely no longer possible, it is highly likely that his PC can be controlled and managed for several years ahead. You have an entire Team of Forum Brothers & Sisters who will provide support along this journey. Good luck on the 30th! MF This is certainly true, that dad could easily be around for quite a few number of years, and have a lot of productivity during that period. Jerry Orbach who played on Law & Order for a decade died in 2004 of prostate cancer- but had stage 4 disease for 10 years, working almost the whole time. Since 2004, of course, there have been further advances, there is a very good chance that your father could be around for a long time.

Men can last many years, continue to work- although that probably isn't your dad because of his age, and hormone treatment can be effective for a decade or longer. Prostate cancer doesn't exempt men from other ailments that he can have concurrently.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dshinnick Diagnosed about a year ago, G6, 5% of one core. PSA 5.4. Bone scan negative. Six months later, PSA of 5.6. Doc said it was an insignificant increase. Another six months. PSA yesterday: 6.06. Darn. Doc did DRE, said he felt nothing. Scheduled another biopsy next week. I'm guessing that first biopsy probably missed some bad cores or that the suspicious core "turned" bad. And, with that rate of increase, I'm also guessing surgery is in my future. Any thoughts? thanks- dave That sounds like a pretty modest rate of increase. A 2nd biopsy is certainly a prudent course of action. PSA isn't specific to cancer, you know. Infections, age, BPH can cause PSA to rise.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer Please help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DJS2017 A week from today Dr. and I will discuss treatment. He says surgery is the only option as far as he is concerned. I'm looking at other solutions, especially Proton, as I'd rather not be whittled on. My biggest fears are permanent incontinence and ED. What say you good folks? Surgery is rarely the only viable option out there- it may be the best option in your case, but "only viable"isn't likely to be that accurate. All urologists are surgeons by trade, of course you can expect that they will have a preference for and definitely believe in the efficacy of their treatments. Definitely should have a 2nd opinion or 2. Radiation, IMRT or brachytherapy, is often a viable option. Proton has good results, but it hasn't proved to be any better than other radiation treatment and is a lot more expensive- your insurance may not cover it.

Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mark H. Hi, I am new here. Yesterday I received a lab test back that stunned me. For many years I have had been treated for adult onset diabetes and high blood pressure (along with meds for cholesterol and lipids). I was so focused on those problems and the related tests that for several years (or more) I went without a PSA test; so I really don't know what my original baseline was after 2011 or so (when it was normal). Today, at nearly 67 my PSA came back at 9.5 and will be seeing my GP in a few days for followup. I don't even know if it is possible to have a 9.5 without cancer, but I am a nervous wreck. It would seem that one should not delay action You have reason to be concerned, but not to panic. 9.5 is significantly elevated, but the PSA test is not specific to Prostate Cancer. In fact, to be 100% accurate, "prostate specific antigen" is a misnomer, as dames can have measurable PSA scores too. PSA can be elevated due to an enlarged prostate, a urinary tract infection, prostate stimulation due to ejaculation, or recipitory anal sex. Probably redoing the PSA test (making sure to avoid the above) and following up if needed with a biopsy is the next step. There is a pretty fair chance that you don't have cancer at all, and even if you do, most cases are very treatable.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed at Age 42

Posts.Content: Excellent, may you continue to receive the goose eggs. Your report reflects another reason why people might want to choose surgery as opposed to radiation. In a successful surgery, the zero score is achieved rather quickly and is pretty much definitive. Had you had successful radiation treatments instead, you might still not have reached your PSA nadir after only a year, and wouldn't necessarily have known it when you did. Creates a lot more uncertainty than just the champagne cork popping occasion your "zero" reading is today.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate I just happened to google "surgery vs radiation prostate cancer forum" and got 684,000 hits! Yes, that's how intense this topic has become. And, it certainly cannot be helpful to newbie's facing life-altering decisions.. Look at the positive of this, AS. The landscape of prostate cancer is changing on a constant basis, not everyone can really see where all of the activity is happening. Its a hopeful situation. Surveillance was less acceptable when I was diagnosed than it is today, just 4 years or so afterward. New radiation protocols have been developed, new diagnostic tools like the genome test are being promoted by Hall of Famer Joe Torre on the radio. A lively conservation is indicative of a constantly changing playing field where not everyone has all of the information.

Posts.Title: PSA result wait time

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by firemana However, he has a fairly low PSA of 2.28. My questions are: 1. even if the tumor grade is indeed aggressive (I am seeking a second opinion on the biopsy right now), does the low PSA value usually indicate bone metastasis has not happened yet? (or the other way round, that bone metastasis usually would cause a higher PSA?) Prostate cells create PSA, which is detected by the test. Bone metastasis are prostate cells that have spread to the bones, they create PSA. A high PSA score would indicate that the patient has a lot more prostate cells, and advanced cancer is a possible explanation that should be explored. A low PSA would indicate the opposite, and if your father had a less aggressive cancer, the doctors would have probably dispensed with the bone scan altogether. All in all, the low PSA doesn't guarantee anything 100%, but is a very hopeful sign.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer diagnosis

Posts.Content: Excellent, may you continue to receive the goose eggs. Your report reflects another reason why people might want to choose surgery as opposed to radiation. In a successful surgery, the zero score is achieved rather quickly and is pretty much definitive. Had you had successful radiation treatments instead, you might still not have reached your PSA nadir after only a year, and wouldn't necessarily have known it when you did. Creates a lot more uncertainty than just the champagne cork popping occasion your "zero" reading is today.

Posts.Title: AS question

Posts.Content: The PSA test is not specific to Prostate Cancer in men that have not received treatment for PC. There is really no advantage to having a 1 or a 3 on the score for men that have prostates. Just try to go to the same lab, and have conditions as similar as possible each time you have the test, so the results are comparable to each other.

Posts.Title: Advice on PSA results for 49 year old

Posts.Content: Treatment at this point in time isn't really urgent with a wee cancer of low grade, like what you have been diagnosed with. You have the luxury of weighing various ideas. If you have the right temperament for it, active surveillance is an option. Urologists are trained surgeons, they believe in it, and due to your young age (63 is young for pc) he is more likely than not going to suggest it and the vast majority of radical prostatectomies in the US are done with the robot nowadays. If you elect that route, you want someone with experience, rp is one of the most technically challenging operations done.

Posts.Content: The problem with AS in your case is that you have a G7 disease diagnosed. Fairly risky, unless you were an octogenarian or older or had significant co-morbidities which make it unlikely you'll live more than 10 years anyhow. To verify that it is indeed Gleason 7- you don't need another biopsy, you can have the biopsy slides from your June 2016 biopsy looked at by someone else. Johns Hopkins will charge you $250 to look at it, the pathologists there are considered to know more about prostate cancer cells than anyone on the planet.

Posts.Title: 2nd Opinion - thoughts on AS

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tok718 The problem is The oncologist is a very long drive away from my fathers home and I fear Driving everyday for treatments will be difficult. My question is : can my father choose another radiology clinic That really depends on your father's insurance coverage and whether he is able and willing to foot more of the bill if he switches to someone that might be "out of network". But of course, he can switch doctors for any reason or no reason. If your dad lives way out in the boonies, it can be a real hassle I'm sure as standard radiation treatment can require like 6 weeks of daily visits. I might be worthwhile to see if SBRT or "cyber knife" treatment is appropriate or available to him. That really reduces the number of visits to about half a dozen and could reduce the travel time and expense for him.

Posts.Title: New Psa results 2.40 from 2.90

Posts.Content: It looks like you haven't had an MRI yet. An MRI can identify hotspots in your prostate, and could be useful. A saturation biopsy is pretty much a major operation, you have to be put under for it. What do you think the saturation biopsy can tell you? I don't know, I'd ask the doctor. An MRI might point out something in you plumbing that's causing a rise in PSA and your cancer really is indolent. I'm not a doctor, by all means hear what he says. I don't think your case is super urgent, you've had an elevated PSA for a decade, but you're only 61

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tinytomtoys Has anyone ever heard if someone getting prostate cancer this young? Im having pain all over body that has gotten worse all started in the last 8 month's I never met anyone that young with prostate cancer. Its certainly "possible" that someone could get PC in their 20's, and medical history does list a handful of men who actually did. But it is exceedingly rare. The average age for a Prostate Cancer diagnosis is 66. There are plenty of diseases that can cause the symptoms you describe. If its bothering you, go to a doctor and get checked out.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Yesterday’s blood draw came back at .068. Just for context, my first detectable PSA first was in January 2017, which was 2 years post op and at that point it was .02. That was followed by .033, .033 (again), .046, .060, and now today’s .068 (this last one was 2 1/2 months since last test, before that it was always 3-3 1/2 months. Now I have appointment with RO on Tuesday, who is going to tell me time to act, then August 3rd with surgeon Uro, who says don’t do anything till .2, based on my pathology, unless velocity starts to ramp up. RO probably holds more weight with me at this point, but I am going to try and have them talk to each other. Try to relax, you have a lot of reason to be positive here. Your PSA score is still considerably under 0.1, you have a top flight surgeon who isn't that excited about it, your pathology report after surgery was fine, your genome report says its low risk. Hear out both doctors, make your best decision, and don't look back.

Your PSA score is still considerably under 0.1, you have a top flight surgeon who isn't that excited about it, your pathology report after surgery was fine, your genome report says its low risk. Hear out both doctors, make your best decision, and don't look back.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by pplexed . What are the forums thoughts, could this be PCA? "could be"?? Sure, anything could be. But its just not that likely From your previous posts, you had urological symptoms and that can cause rise in PSA scores. Prostatitis can be very frustrating to the patient and doctor to treat. A lot of infections are non-bacterial and aren't affected by antibiotics like cipro. I think your doctor is doing the right thing by you. If this starts to really bother you, there are other antibiotics that might help your urinary symptoms, so give him a call.

Posts.Title: New Psa results 2.40 from 2.90

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TinkerbellRM27 What steps did your doctor go through in order to ensure you were eligible for surgery? From the perspective of other surgery suitability, did your uro have you see a cardio doc? get a physical? meet with an anesthesiologist? Thanks! The steps taken to see if the cancer has already spread varies from patient to patient- depending on their PSA levels and gleason score. When I was assessed for a radical prostatectomy, I asked (my mum had a pet scan after she was diagnosed with lung ca) about scanning. The surgeon said it wasn't necessary in my case with my numbers. It will be different with your father The cardio tests aren't really to determine "suitability" for surgery, but are mostly for the anesthesiologist. I guess if the pre-surgery physical indicated really serious co-morbidities, it could preclude surgery entirely, but that's really not its purpose.

Posts.Title: Ensuring eligibility for surgery

Posts.Content: You bring up two points here and they are both valid. Men who are healthier and in the prime of life really should be approaching their cancers more aggressively that those who are older or have serious co-morbidities such as yourself. Different men have different resources, different insurance situations and sometimes live in remote areas where every option isn't necessarily available. As far as the advice that people are given and receive, remember that far more than just the opening poster are reading the advice. If the man is unable to act on advice because their insurance or national plan won't pay for it, they don't have the money, etc., someone else reading this forum months or years in the future might be able to.

Posts.Title: Worried Over PSA Levels

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sandra2529 But would any of you know what the chances are if it already spread out of the prostate? I know his numbers would help and every case is different. I’m just so scared, sad and just losing sleep over this. Thank you all and wish you all the best. There are statistical compilations called the "Partin tables", which can give you an idea of whether or not the disease has spread- based upon other cases in the past. But you have to know the numbers. Prostate cancer moves pretty slowly, so it might not have spread and "aggressive" is sort of a flexible, subjective adjective so it really doesn't say anything definitive. The doctor may have used the term "aggressive" to try and light a fire under a reluctant patient that he really wants to get into treatment.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 Had DaVinci RP in early August, with surgeon said that I should have external beam radiation upon healing from surgery. This is to address any cancer cells not removed during surgery. Is this what you cal salvage radiation? What you are having is call adjuvant radiation, as you getting it right away after surgery. Salvage radiation refers to treatments given patients who had surgery, but then had a rise in PSA scores afterwards showing recurrence.

Posts.Title: What to do?

Posts.Content: PSA is definitely not a specific test for cancer, except for men who have already had treatment for prostate cancer. PSA can increase or decrease due to infections, prostatitis, sexual activity, strenuous exercise and I'm sure there are other reasons. The use of the PSA in cancer screening merely gives a clinician an idea as to whether or not further steps should be taken to actually identify and diagnose PC. A movement of your PSA from 2.56 to 2.16 isn't likely to be that significant at all

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 A big step forward IMHO, a website that allows one to compare the performance of surgeons in the USA. And YES (!) prostate surgery is one of the specialties for which there is data: Rating surgeons based on results can be problematic I think. The top men often get the most difficult and challenging assignments, the ones where a good result isn't always possible, at least compared to easier or more typical situations. I think that's the real challenge here, making sure you are not comparing apples to oranges.

Posts.Title: What to do?

Posts.Content: Brachytherapy can certain cure prostate cancer, its a proven treatment. Listen to your doctor, see what they say. What's you're PSA score, how many cores? "Stage 2" for PC means that the doctor felt it when doing your DRE. There are a fair number of false positives there. Gleason 6, if you have a small volume of disease and only a modestly elevated PSA may not require treatment at all at this time. Its certainly not an emergency from what you know right now, so you have time to seek a 2nd opinion if you like.

Posts.Title: Doctor 1 or Doctor 2 or Maybe 3?

Posts.Content: Prostate cancer is really rare for someone of your age, only being 40 years old. Further, both your PSA score as well as all of the symptoms that you are having really don't sound like any kind of PC. Most PC patients have a biopsy after a suspicious PSA score, which you don't have. I don't think a biopsy is really worthwhile for you now, but since you are suffering and haven't received any diagnosis/explanation from the specialist you did consult, I'd suggest that you might want to see a different specialist, maybe one at a major academic medical center.

Posts.Title: PSA over 100

Posts.Content: A 20 fold increase in PSA score over a single year seems a lot more likely to be caused by an infection or other trauma to the urinary system than prostate cancer. Just because you had a negative DRE and no symptoms doesn't mean you don't have an infection. The urologist will probably order another PSA test and maybe give you a course of cipro to take first. If your PSA is still elevated, maybe an MRI, maybe go straight to a biopsy. Remember that the PSA test doesn't necessarily mean cancer, except for men who have already received treatment for prostate cancer

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA

Posts.Content: With cancer on both sides of your prostate, a fairly large volume of Gleason Grade 4 cancer in your biopsy, and a double digit PSA score, the next step is likely to be a bone scan and/or CT scans and MRI's to stage the disease. If the doctors feel its still confined to your prostate from the tests, they will likely recommend surgery as well likely to prescribe other aggressive measure to look to cure it.

Posts.Title: Interpretation of detailed biopsy result

Posts.Content: The brother in law sounds like he has a fairly aggressive case- a PSA of 100 would indicate a PSA doubling rate of less than 12 months. If his PSA were at a "4", four years ago, and it was just doubling every 12 months, it would be 64 today. If his PSA were more than 4 last time he had a physical, they would have kept a closer eye on him. However, if the Mayo Clinic is ready to operate, the scans indicate that the cancer hasn't spread beyond the prostate and that is definitely a good sign. Radical prostatectomy is a curative therapy-they don't operate if they don't think they can cure you. The Mayo Clinic is a world class facility, you can't go wrong there. Northwestern isn't as "elite" but is still a major academic medical center, with a great reputation.

The book says that salvage radiation is considerably less successful once the PSA gets past 0.5. If the goal is a cure, this may be the patient's last chance. Of course, this guy also has a lot of co-morbidities, the question is how long does he have to live anyhow? Does he have long enough to have the PC come back and kill him or not?

Posts.Title: Thinking of passing on salvage radiation.

Posts.Content: Primary signet ring carcinoma is a fairly rare variant of pc, I think you'd want to have the slides rechecked to be sure on this diagnosis- it could make a difference in the exact treatment plan. The good news is that men with localized prostate cancer still have a very high rate of survival-99% over 10 years-and you should have him around for many more years. Many effective treatments to cure and to slow down the progressive of pc, and new ones coming on line every year.

The truth be told, the PSA test isn't even specific to the prostate, and woman can produce it as well. It is not time to panic yet

Posts.Title: MSKCC Study - No Advantage to Surgery in Low Risk Younger Men

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Woodman Thanks for the clarification, guys. Looks like my prostate is expanding every year. I'm in the process of moving to a new urologist and just got a copy of all my tests, biopsies, etc from the last doc. Two years ago they said it was 33 grams. Last year, 50 grams. Now it's 61 grams. I've had prostatitis off and on for years and years. Wonder if that tends to enlarge it. Prostatitis is an infection, an infected finger swells up, one would think an infected prostate would do the same thing. Good luck with the new urologist. Some of those guys are a little gauche, a little crude, but that doesn't mean they aren't a good doctor. The doctor I have, when we first met, actually stuck his hand out for me to shake it- as if I didn't know where his hand was before he came into the exam room.

Posts.Title: Prostate size and volume calculations

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Woodman Thanks for the clarification, guys. Looks like my prostate is expanding every year. I'm in the process of moving to a new urologist and just got a copy of all my tests, biopsies, etc from the last doc. Two years ago they said it was 33 grams. Last year, 50 grams. Now it's 61 grams. I've had prostatitis off and on for years and years. Wonder if that tends to enlarge it. Prostatitis is an infection, an infected finger swells up, one would think an infected prostate would do the same thing. Good luck with the new urologist. Some of those guys are a little gauche, a little crude, but that doesn't mean they aren't a good doctor. The doctor I have, when we first met, actually stuck his hand out for me to shake it- as if I didn't know where his hand was before he came into the exam room.

Active Surveillance is just a deferment of treatment, hopefully for a long, indefinite and perhaps even permanent basis.

Posts.Title: My questions for new Urologist (Yale Smilow)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis • Do finasteride and Tamsulosin confound PSA results and impact state of my cancer? Finisteride aka Prosper does affect the PSA score- but doesn't affect prostate cancer one way or another. The general rule is that it reduces PSA scores in half. Always make sure that your urologist knows what offer medications or supplements you are on, the PSA test is not particular to Prostate Cancer except in men who have already received treatment.

The book says that salvage radiation is considerably less successful once the PSA gets past 0.5. If the goal is a cure, this may be the patient's last chance. Of course, this guy also has a lot of co-morbidities, the question is how long does he have to live anyhow? Does he have long enough to have the PC come back and kill him or not?

Posts.Content: Please get on the horn and talk to your urologist about this, and see what he has to say. You are fortunate that you are being treated at a world class facility by one of the world's foremost experts on prostate cancer prognostication. Dr. Partin has earned the coveted Golden Cystoscope Award, and that kind of expertise doesn't come easily. Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy this month

Posts.Content: The general consensus is that Proton Therapy is effective, but no more so that other, much less expensive forms of radiation. As a result, in 2018, its likely that your insurance coverage isn't going to cover it. Further, if you do go for it, they only do Proton treatments in a limited number of venues, so you will also likely have travel expenses for the month you have it. Proton therapy is proven very effective for certain childhood tumors, but those cancers are quite rare. To pay for these expensive machines, they would really like more customers and they were hopeful that a popular disease like Prostate Cancer could be treated better with protons. Just not proven yet, at least by the insurance companies.

Posts.Title: New member, no dx yet, psa 29

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Hi Scott, I agree with Southsider regarding the use of the prostate supplement. You are taking a LOT more than the recommended dose which will almost definitely reduce your PSA. Saw Palmetto is frequently used for symptoms of BPH, not Pca. You would do well to stop using 'natural alternatives' There is nothing out there that will do anything for Pca. I think even the recommended dosages of supplements can affect the PSA level, not just excessive dosages. At the very least, let the doctor know what you are on, so he can try and interpret the PSA numbers that you do generate. I agree that saw palmetto won't do anything for pc, but it could help other symptoms of bph that he might be suffering from.

Posts.Title: Proton Therapy Advice?

Posts.Content: A high PSA isn't cancer specific, infections or non cancerous cysts can cause a rise in the score as well. Usually surgery isn't done on men this old, at least here in America. Although if he's in good shape, there is no reason why not. Radical prostatectomy- whether open or davinci is a challenging and complex surgery, if he decides to have it, he will definitely want an experienced surgeon

Posts.Title: New member, no dx yet, psa 29

Posts.Content: You might have cancer, but your urinary systems actually make a case that you might have other reasons for your disturbingly elevated PSA score. Most prostate cancers are asymptomatic at an early stage. Being fat, riding around all day in a car, can't be good for your urinary system, but neither are a cause for cancer. Prostate infections can cause PSA scores to rise, ditto for VD like gonorrhea or chlamydia can cause both your urinary symptoms as well as the PSA score. Good luck on your doctor visit, keep a positive attitude. There is a decent chance that you don't have cancer at all, and if you do, there is a good chance that the cancer is very curable.

Posts.Title: New member, no dx yet, psa 29

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis • Do finasteride and Tamsulosin confound PSA results and impact state of my cancer? Finisteride aka Prosper does affect the PSA score- but doesn't affect prostate cancer one way or another. The general rule is that it reduces PSA scores in half. Always make sure that your urologist knows what offer medications or supplements you are on, the PSA test is not particular to Prostate Cancer except in men who have already received treatment.

Posts.Title: My questions for new Urologist (Yale Smilow)

Posts.Content: A 2nd opinion on the slides is definitely in order here. But if stands as is or worse, you will definitely need to consider radiation or surgery. As far as radical prostatectomy, you should be aware that whether it is done open style or with the help of the robot, r.p. is one of the most technically challenging surgeries out there. You are definitely going to want to ask your urologic surgeon about his experience doing these operation, it isn't amateur hour.

Posts.Title: My story so far...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mom2two Seeing the surgeon on the 14th to discuss results. Still very low, but 3 consecutive increases each 6 months apart: 0.015, 0.027, and this one now at 0.040 I'm am very worried about my dad.....is this a recurrence? Its not considered a recurrence unless it goes about 0.4, that's the usual standard. Yes, its going in the wrong direction, but its still 90% below the usual recurrence threshold. Salvage radiation is designed to take care of recurrences, and does work in many cases.

Posts.Title: The Decipher Test

Posts.Content: Ideally, they would like to do an MRI first, before a biopsy. The idea of the MRI is to identify "hot spots" in your prostate to know where to sample from. As far as taking medicine to pee, lots of men have that. Turn on the radio or TV for 30 minutes, you'll see at least a couple of ads for flomax or viagra or herbal supplements to get your plumbing in order. You aren't alone.

Posts.Title: Husband now a Member of the Club

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WifeinWorry I know its not so much what level the PSA is as to how much it jumps in a short period of time, correct? So if its 2.4 one month and next month jumps to 3.1, do they consider this alarming? So every month since maybe 5 months ago it has increased, but this one was the biggest jump. How do we consider what difference in numbers needs attention? The meaning of a jump in PSA is really variable, depending on whether its sustained, the patient is in or out of treatment and what treatment they have received, whether someone has even been diagnosed. If a doctor ordered the PSA tests, he's probably the best person to ask about its significance in your husbands case

Posts.Title: The Decipher Test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jake XYZ Is going to a cancer center worth it - like Anderson in TX or Sloane Kettering? I do live about an hour or so from Johns Hopkins and could go there for a second opinion. I'm wary of urologists who "boast" (cant think of a better or proper word) about how many radical prostatectomies they have done and think that for them, surgery will always be their first choice. Any advice is welcome. Thanks in advance. Radical prostatectomy is one of the most technically challenging surgeries, particularly among popular operations. You definitely want someone with a lot of experience to cut you, if that's the way you go. Boasting about their number of surgeries is good information for you. You want someone with at least 300 under their belt. As far as surgery being their "first choice", urologists are trained surgeons. Its what they were trained to do, and its their livelihood, they believe in the efficacy of the treatment and their ability to do it. So of course they have a bias toward it.

As far as radical prostatectomy, you should be aware that whether it is done open style or with the help of the robot, r.p. is one of the most technically challenging surgeries out there. Posts.Title: Hormones and moods

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Onlyamonk I am new to this site, and have questions regarding whether I am a candidate for focal laser ablation. Am I in the right place? Focal therapies are pretty new in regards to prostate cancer, the doctors who devised the treatment can answer your question in regards to this. The problem with focal therapy- as opposed to treating the entire prostate as RT and surgery do- is making sure they take out all of the cancer. PC is usually not one tumor, but several small tumors. Being able to see all the tumors is the problem they face, so they can aim the laser and get it all. I guess you are indeed a "candidate" for the treatment, at least until the doctor doing it tells you otherwise.

Posts.Title: Questions after 2nd urologist visit

Posts.Content: There are rare prostate cancers which do not produce PSA, and I guess is "possible" he could have it. But they are very rare, so try not to be worried about it, and listen to the biopsy results with a positive attitude expecting that the situation will be none too serious and in any event, something that can be treated or resolved on its own. BPH is very common, especially among older men, that's why you can't watch TV for more than 5 minutes without seeing a flomax ad. Its a natural process, the prostate grows over the years regardless of whether the man has pc or not. The prostate for a 20 yo man is the size of a walnut, for a 40 yo- a golf ball, for a 60 yo- a lemon, for a man of 80- a softball. BPH can be managed, I'm sure it will in your father's case.

Posts.Title: First post, Just got the news......

Posts.Content: Back pain can be caused by a lot of things, and so can urinary problems. But I really would doubt it would be prostate cancer. PC is quite uncommon for men of your age. Further, an ordinary prostate cancer would be creating a lot more than 1 ng of PSA if it was large enough to cause urinary and bone symptoms. The only way it would be possible for prostate cancer symptoms and such a low PSA is if you had a rare version of prostate cancer. It would be a real double rarity both because of your young age as well as a rare cancer, for PC to be your problem. I guess it would be technically possible, but very, very unlikely.

Posts.Content: Infections/prostatitis can cause an elevated PSA reading. Prostatitis is very hard to get rid of, particularly non-bacterial forms. I had a few bouts of it in my 30's, not recently treated for it. Caused me symptoms, but they went away. But when I had my biopsy,a lot of lnflammation of the prostate was noted, even though I hadn't had symptoms for many years.

Posts.Title: Heading for a second biopsy maybe?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor How does one verify the data / success rates / side effect percentages provided by my particular surgeon? Trust but Verify - HOW? Going by the record of the institution or group is the way to go. The problem with comparing the cure/side effects stats with individuals in the same group is that often the toughest cases are given to the top guys. Of course, someone with more complex case is less likely to get an optimal result regardless of who the surgeon is, but the top man in the group gives him his best chance. These kinds of cases and bring down his stats. Junior guys, the rank and file surgeons, get the more routine cases. Not that these guys aren't good, but comparing their record with relatively "easy" cases with the top guys getting a lot more difficult ones, its like comparing apples to oranges. I was told the top man at UPMC Urology doesn't do RP's on Gleason 6 cases, leaves them for the other guys.

Posts.Title: New QOL study has much higher RP incontinence percentages than I find elsewhere

Posts.Content: With just 1 core out of 24 positive as a Gleason 6, if you have the right temperament, you could be a candidate for active surveillance and defer treatment. The key thing to know about radical prostatectomy is that it is a very challenging surgery to do, so you would want someone very experienced operating on you. Make sure you ask Dr. Su how many hundreds of RP's he's done robotically and what his success has been.

Posts.Content: You may want to get a 2nd opinion on the pathology of your biopsy. Determining the correct gleason score is considered pretty tricky. A lot of patients send their biopsy slides to Johns Hopkins, a Dr. Epstein that works there is reputed to know more about the appearance of prostate cancer cells than anyone really should. It can be risky to wait too long with GS7 cancer, no need to get angry with your doctor on this. Sure, its possible that you could be fine without treatment, but its his duty to let you know the risks and to make a recommendation.

Posts.Content: With just 1 core out of 24 positive as a Gleason 6, if you have the right temperament, you could be a candidate for active surveillance and defer treatment. The key thing to know about radical prostatectomy is that it is a very challenging surgery to do, so you would want someone very experienced operating on you. Make sure you ask Dr. Su how many hundreds of RP's he's done robotically and what his success has been.
Posts.Title: Surprise

Posts.Content: I think your doctor is giving you pretty sound advice. Only a biopsy can diagnose PC, an MRI might point out specific areas of concern in your prostate but can't say if you actually have cancer. Your PSA score is elevated and a cause of concern, and you could have PC, but it probably isn't the cause of your symptoms. Prostatitis is a difficult and frustrating problem, often recurs, and is often resistant to antibiotics, and can raise PSA. But it isn't cancer.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance in Younger Men?

Posts.Content: There is a good chance that you don't have PC at all. PSA is not prostate cancer specific. All that diverticulitis and prostatitis can cause trauma to the urinary system and release more PSA. If you don't trust your PCP's recommendation for a urologist, you can certainly call the major academic medical center near where you live and make an appointment there. You might need a new PCP if you don't trust him to do what he does. Biopsies do carry a risk of infection, but there is a new method called the "Precision Point" system which doesn't approach the prostate through the rectum and carries a lot lower chance of infection. Its only in a limited number of locations now.

Posts.Content: Your PSA score is virtually zero, and it isn't going anywhere- looks pretty good to this non-medical mind. Just for your information, even though it is called the "prostate specific antigen", it really isn't absolutely specific to the prostate. Dames have PSA scores greater than zero, even though they don't have prostates at all. They usually aren't tested for it clinically, but researchers are looking to seek if there is a connection between PSA and cancer in women.

Posts.Title: Choosing surgeon

Posts.Content: Dad's numbers and testing results just don't seem to add up logically. Maybe you are omitting a detail or didn't hear something, but I'd definitely be looking at a 2nd opinion here. People can live for a long, long time with metastatic prostrate cancer, and your father's case doesn't sound like it would be that aggressive, but then it didn't sound like it would create mets either. About 20 years ago, I met a young man who was about 40 or so, and he told me his story. He wasn't feeling well, he went to the hospital with a pneumonia, and they gave him a complete workup. The doctor comes to his room to give him the verdict, showed him the X-rays and explained the spots on his bones were mets. He had lung cancer and it had already spread and was incurable. Needless to say, he was pretty bummed out, but got up to leave the hospital. But they convinced him to stay to take a needle in the chest and drain his thoracic cavity. Afterwards, the took another X-ray- and then walked back the diagnosis, changing it to rheumatoid arthritis. Mistakes are made. Things aren't always what they appear to be.

Posts.Title: elevated PSA at age 52

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by goatts Thanks for the encouraging words Highlander and Southsider. The DRE showed enlarged prostate with a hard spot so I do have cancer. How bad is the question ... A positive DRE is not an infallible sign of cancer. 1000 men were given the DRE- 21 had true positives and 85 had false positives. Based on this alone, a positive DRE alone means you have a one in 5 chance of cancer. Its a good reason to have a biopsy, and you're scheduled. http://www.medicine.ox.ac.uk/bandoli...d74/b74-7.html

Until you have the biopsy, and get the diagnosis, you really don't know if you have cancer, or if robotic surgery will be appropriate.
