Posts.Title: Finding an experienced surgeon. How to?

Posts.Content: Dad's numbers and testing results just don't seem to add up logically. Maybe you are omitting a detail or didn't hear something, but I'd definitely be looking at a 2nd opinion here. People can live for a long, long time with metastatic prostrate cancer, and your father's case doesn't sound like it would be that aggressive, but then it didn't sound like it would create mets either. About 20 years ago, I met a young man who was about 40 or so, and he told me his story. He wasn't feeling well, he went to the hospital with a pneumonia, and they gave him a complete workup. The doctor comes to his room to give him the verdict, showed him the X-rays and explained the spots on his bones were mets. He had lung cancer and it had already spread and was incurable. Needless to say, he was pretty bummed out, but got up to leave the hospital. But they convinced him to stay to take a needle in the chest and drain his thoracic cavity. Afterwards, the took another X-ray- and then walked back the diagnosis, changing it to rheumatoid arthritis. Mistakes are made. Things aren't always what they appear to be.

Posts.Content: Your urinary symptoms are really unlikely to be from cancer. But if don't feel good about this doctor, by all means see another one. If this surgeon is short and impatient, that's not a good sign. Prostate cancer is a marathon, and as such prostate cancer patients are among the most informed with the most questions, your relationship is likely to last many years with him.

Posts.Content: 1 core and just 10% involved isn't a large volume of cancer. But Gleason 3+4 is somewhat problematic depending on the percentage of "4". Still, he could be a candidate for surveillance especially due to his age. One thing I would do is to have a 2nd opinion on the biopsy slides, send them to Johns Hopkins. A pathologist there knows more about prostate cells than anyone really should.

Posts.Title: Fluctuating PSA

Posts.Content: in spite of the fact that you were positive for G6 prostate cancer in 20% of one core, your doctor feels ok with just doing AS at this point in time. That's certainly a legitimate opinion, even though there is a chance that somewhere down the line - maybe not that far down the line- you'll need treatment. If you are dissatisfied with this treatment plan as you seem, then you really need to get a 2nd opinion on this. The first urologist I went to was anxious to operate with a similar enough biopsy report. Personally, I would put a lot of weight to the opinion advising you to defer surgery. Urologists are surgeons by trade, and the radical prostatectomy is their bread and butter. They believe in surgery and have faith in their ability to perform it and believe it can help their patients. An opinion that you receive that is contrary to the doctor's mindset and philosophy as well as financial benefit, is one that should be taken very seriously. You should definitely look to make an appointment with another expert, based on your biopsy report, you certainly have time to do that.

A virtual no-brainer to the first urologist that I spoke to. Things certainly have changed.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PCHearn I have a general question about recurrent prostate cancer and Active Surveillance. That’s AS with a capital A and a capital S. Not just watchful waiting. I’ve read a lot, a whole lot, about AS, but I can’t seem to find anything about AS after surgery. It seems on this forum that once it is determined that the cancer is back, then it’s time to have radiation done ASAP. And it seems that the earlier (.03 vs .20) you have radiation the better. No one seems to talk about AS at this point. Even though you are under surveillance, and actively being watched, they don't call it "active surveillance" in the post-treatment phase. Deciding when it will be the best time to intervene with salvage radiation treatment is sort of tricky. If you are dissatisfied or perplexed with your own doctor's decision on this, you can always get a 2nd opinion. In fact, you probably should

Posts.Title: Fluctuating PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sw1218 it seems to me as if he's still monitoring for cancer and not treating the inflammation which may bring down the PSA. why does my psa keep elevating? i'm glad it's not a 9 and i'm MOST HAPPY it's not cancer, but i feel if he treats the prostatitis or inflammation, then maybe my psa'll go down. i take saw palmetto 320mg. my symptoms are not unbearable, but i would feel much better if we could find a better way to bring down my psa. what are your thoughts? You said "symptoms are not unbearable", the question is what are your symptoms? An elevated PSA score is a sign, not a symptom at all. If that's what you are counting as a symptom, you are doing all you can. The doctor can give you antibiotics if he suspects bacterial prostatitis (that will reduce PSA score), or give you proscar or flomax if you have bph. Proscar will definitely reduce PSA scores, usually by half.

Posts.Title: Need hope and stories: PSA in 100's still alive, still living

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by andy12 65 years of age, PSA was 4.2 in March, doctor did biopsy; I also have a brother with pc. 12 cores, 2 were 5%, Gleason 6. Doctor recommended active surveillance. PSA in July, four months later, was 3.1. I was surprised by this, expecting it to be the same or higher, but not lower. He gave an explanation that I didn't totally understand. Anyone have experience with this occurrence, or knowledge of it? Thank you. (BTW, I like my doctor a lot; he is excellent). PSA isn't specifically a test for cancer, except in patients that have already had definitive treatment like prostatectomy or radiation. PSA can go up and down for various reasons unrelated to cancer, even if you have cancer. I had a PSA at 4.2 in Nov 13, 4.5 in August 14, 3.5 in February this year and this month 3.6. You're experience and test results aren't particularly surprising.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and dropping PSA?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by vingal Any thoughts on what he might suggest and any questions I should ask? You'll want to know what you're gleason score is, you might also want to have the slides looked at for a 2nd opinion by a different lab. I had mine shipped over the Johns Hopkins, it cost like $250. A positive DRE isn't good, ups the staging of the cancer. Since the doctor is a trained surgeon, its most likely that he'll recommend surgery particularly if you are under 70 and in otherwise good health. The vast majority of RP's in America are done with the robot, that's his most likely recommendation.

Posts.Title: Psa 40 and scared

Posts.Content: in spite of the fact that you were positive for G6 prostate cancer in 20% of one core, your doctor feels ok with just doing AS at this point in time. That's certainly a legitimate opinion, even though there is a chance that somewhere down the line - maybe not that far down the line- you'll need treatment. If you are dissatisfied with this treatment plan as you seem, then you really need to get a 2nd opinion on this. The first urologist I went to was anxious to operate with a similar enough biopsy report. Personally, I would put a lot of weight to the opinion advising you to defer surgery. Urologists are surgeons by trade, and the radical prostatectomy is their bread and butter. They believe in surgery and have faith in their ability to perform it and believe it can help their patients. An opinion that you receive that is contrary to the doctor's mindset and philosophy as well as financial benefit, is one that should be taken very seriously. You should definitely look to make an appointment with another expert, based on your biopsy report, you certainly have time to do that.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by czw1000 I think given my family history, regular DREs are warranted. All PCP type doctors get trained in giving a DRE. The key parts you can notice are two. They should do any blood draw for a PSA test BEFORE doing the DRE. DRE does push up PSA scores. The other part is that the proper posture for a DRE is bending over with your hands on the exam table. You should not be lying down for it.

Posts.Title: Seeking New York City general practitioner with experience with digital rectal exams

Posts.Content: You should really just go to the same lab for all of your PSA tests- then you'd have a more valid way of comparing the numbers. It really shouldn't be like that, but different labs use different methods sometimes yielding different scores A sudden rise, and sudden fall in PSA scores doesn't indicate cancer at all- that's a good sign. As far as DRE, its useful enough, but from the doctor's position, he can't really feel your whole prostate from that, so a negative DRE is not conclusive. 4 years ago, I took a biopsy after a single reading north of 4- they sold it to me that there was nothing to it but i was 57 and working and it was a day off with pay. Medical science has moved forward, I think you're probably safe just to keep an eye on it for 6 months and see where your PSA is going, but I'm not a doctor.

Posts.Title: PSA Scores are all over the Map. What's next - REPOST from General Cancer Forum

Posts.Content: Because of your youth, the doctor will probably suggest surgery, although radiation is equally effective and can be considered as well. The key with surgery is choosing a surgeon with a lot of experience and success in the operation. Radical prostatectomy is a very technically challenging operation, whether its done conventionally or robotically. Both the open and robotic surgeries are equally effective, the main advantage of robotic is a faster recovery afterwards. Talking to the doctor about his experience in doing r.p's needs to be something to touch on, you'll want a surgeon that does these procedures frequently and has done 300 or more. The advantage of surgery are that they send your prostate to the lab to be sliced and diced, the information can determine if they will recommend adjunctive radiation or ADT right away. Another advantage is that successful treatment from surgery will give you a zero reading on the PSA test afterwards, it doesn't go quite that low with radiation, or as quickly, making it a tad more difficult to determine the success of the treatment.

Posts.Title: My Hereditary Connection To PC

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DONNIE Hi, I had PC in 2012, finished 45 treatments of IGRT in Nov. of 2012. My latest PSA test were 1/22/15-0.4, 7/22/15-0.3, 1/18/16-0.4, 7/19/16-0.6. The urologist is not to concerned, will test in 3 months. What do you guys think? Sounds like your doctor is fairly concerned, scheduling your PSA in 3 months instead of 6 months. PSA tests do fluctuate, figuring out the nadir of your PSA is a little bit different with radiation treatments as opposed to surgery patients that go for the "Zero" reading. Seems like a reasonable plan on the part of the doctor to see if your latest reading is a bit of an outlier and not indicative of cancer returning and progressing, before prescribing another round of radiation.

Posts.Title: How concerned should I be?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TLDinMD Wow, what a process. I didn’t realize how long it took from diagnosis to actually starting treatment. We met with the RO this week and the best course of treatment for my Dad is external radiation and hormone injections. He will get his first injection in January, wait one month then have gold markers placed in the prostate, 2 weeks later get CT scan and the little tattoo markers, then 2 weeks later start radiation. Holy hell! So we are talking end of March before he starts radiation. That's a known protocol, to give ADT in advance of the radiation treatment. Its called "neoadjuvent hormone therapy" and some patients have received this order of treatment for a number of years. The idea I think is to reduce the size of the prostate, which can make the radiation more effective, although you should certainly ask the doctor prescribing it for the reasons and details. Prostate Cancer is a marathon, most patients stick around a lot longer than folks with other cancers. It seems to be moving right along

Posts.Title: EBRT and HT not for several months

Posts.Content: The odds would seem to be better that your elevated PSA is being caused by prostatitis instead of cancer in your case. You have a history of it, and its an ailment that stick with some men for decades. Further, what's your age? PC is pretty rare among young guys under 50, and the younger you are the less likely your elevated PSA is caused by cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikesimm My latest PSA is 3.2, down from April when it was 5.02, and August PSA 3.9. I haven't had any treatment yet (schedule for surgery Oct. 23). Anyone have any experience with this? I'm also concerned about "low PSA PC" indicating a more agressive cancer. Has this occured with anyone? Thanks! Mike The "low PSA" types of PC are ailments like "ductal PC" or "small cell PC", that would have turned up in the biopsy report. I wouldn't worry too much, I'd think the lower PSA is a good sign that your disease is still organ confined.

Posts.Title: PSA Moving Lower - Before Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RAD1964 He has not been scheduled for a bone scan or any other follow-up test, including genetic, as his urologist does not think it necessary (his words). This puzzles me, as I have since learned that scans and genetic tests are imperative. My bottom line question is: how much time do we have to make a decision on treatment? Any thoughts you can share with me about time frames would be most appreciated. Thanks so much, CPG Due to fact that your husband's PSA score is only moderately elevated and the biopsy shows that he is an intermediate risk, the urologist probably thinks a bone scan is pointless. The husband's numbers make it very unlikely that there are metastases and even less likely that any could be detected by the test. PC is most usually slow growing. Usually the fastest they will operate on is 8 weeks after the biopsy- waiting for the prostate to settle down after that abuse. A Gleason score of 7 usually means treatment, especially for a such a young man. But I think you definitely have time to get additional opinions and look to make a decision several months down the line. If you decide on AS, you can always change your mind you know

Posts.Content: After thanksgiving is fine, but you probably wouldn't want to schedule surgery after Christmas in the same way. Christmas is the beginning of archery season, and a lot of urologists are going to be busy doing emergency surgery for pierced bladders to deal expeditiously with a prostatectomy.

This puzzles me, as I have since learned that scans and genetic tests are imperative. My bottom line question is: how much time do we have to make a decision on treatment? Any thoughts you can share with me about time frames would be most appreciated. Thanks so much, CPG Due to fact that your husband's PSA score is only moderately elevated and the biopsy shows that he is an intermediate risk, the urologist probably thinks a bone scan is pointless. The husband's numbers make it very unlikely that there are metastases and even less likely that any could be detected by the test. PC is most usually slow growing. Usually the fastest they will operate on is 8 weeks after the biopsy- waiting for the prostate to settle down after that abuse. A Gleason score of 7 usually means treatment, especially for a such a young man. But I think you definitely have time to get additional opinions and look to make a decision several months down the line. If you decide on AS, you can always change your mind you know

Do you think they will suggest radiation after surgery due to the number of Positive cores and % along with the +DRE ? You made a good selection, that's one of the highest rated hospitals in the country for PC. Its tough to say what they'll say as far as needing radiation after surgery. The gleason scores, and whether or not the margins are positive are the things they look at. If you get upgraded, its a probably. Otherwise, they'll probably just wait a few months, and use your PSA tests to determine if its needed.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Results in, now what?

Posts.Content: Both surgery and radiation treatments have similar sets of side effects. The main difference is that you get the side effects up front with surgical treatment and then you look to improve. With radiation, its the opposite, less side effects to start, but you pay for it later. As a result, older guys- in their 60's and 70's are more likely to go for the radiation- they'll miss out on some of the years of side effects as they'll be past their life expectancies when they come down. Even 10 is a very high PSA score, especially for someone who is only 37. Does he have chronic prostatitis or an enlarged prostate, they usually don't do screening PSA tests until a man reaches at least 40 and in many cases 50 or older. If he has surgery, his problems with that will disappear.

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I have a question. Radiation is suppose to kill the cancer cells, because they are by nature weaker cells, and spare the healthy cells. What stops the radiate prostate from continuing to produce cancer cells? In radiation treatment for prostate cancer, the whole prostate is treated- not just the tumor cells. The goal of the radiologists is to target the treatment just on that organ, and to avoid having it hit other organs and structures nearby.

Posts.Title: Worried about my number

Posts.Content: There are other treatments for BPH. Medications like Proscar, as well as surgeries or PAE. The problem is that you are already receiving brachytherapy, a doctor would have to tell you whether or not you can "switch" at this point in time. The radiation changes your prostate, and it might not react the same way. If Flomax is otherwise effective, a lot to be said for using an antidepressant for the meantime anyhow.

Posts.Title: Pathology Second Opinions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by alazar14 Hi All, I'm 28 years old and seem to have most symptoms of PC. My Primary doctor thinks I may have a severe prostatitis, but has not done any exams on me for this, and suggested I go see a Urologist. I have an appointment with a Urologist tomorrow to do the rectal exam. . Prostate Cancer is quite rare for young guys and prostatitis is pretty common, I can see where your pcp would tilt a lot more in that direction. The worrying and anxiety is what's really killing you right now, maybe the doctor will give you some Miltowns when you go in tomorrow. You will not get a diagnosis of PC tomorrow, you know. Only a biopsy can make the diagnosis, if the urologist thinks PC is a possibility, you'll have to come back in a couple of weeks and it will probably be another week before the pathology report comes down. You have to get it together, this is going to take a little time.

Posts.Title: 28 Year old and have most symptoms of PC

Posts.Content: After you have the radical prostatectomy, or radiation treatment for that matter, the PSA test is what is used to detect a return of cancer. If you don't have a prostate, your PSA score should be a zero. If It is above that, it means you still have prostate cells and prostate cancer.

If the RO were to advise you to do radiation right away, I think you should really consider doing it.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dieselsdog HI all, I'm new to the forum and to cancer. A little bit about myself. I'm 66, fairly healthy, and have no symptoms. . Making a long story short after a biopsy(2 week's ago) my Gleason scores are three 6's and one 7. I decided AS was the right thing for me. My doctor did send my specimen out for Polaris testing . Maybe that'll change things. So, after all that I guess I'm here for support, guidance, or whatever. Thanks all for taking the time to read this. "Its your prostate, your decision", as Hall of Fame catcher Joe Torre likes to say on the radio. But most doctors would not recommend AS for someone as young as yourself and in good shape, with Gleason 7 cancer. I don't know about Polaris testing, but genome testing is a rapidly developing field, and that sounds like a good idea.

Posts.Title: New to cancer

Posts.Content: I think you're worrying too much. If you trust your doctor, listen to him. If he detects you might have something which is outside his comfort zone- something like prostate cancer, he's trained to refer you to a specialist. That's his job. No one can really tell if you have "latent cancer" lurking in your prostate or anywhere else. Since there is no way to detect it , or to treat it, no point in thinking about it.

Posts.Title: Not sure what to do

Posts.Content: The odds would seem to be better that your elevated PSA is being caused by prostatitis instead of cancer in your case. You have a history of it, and its an ailment that stick with some men for decades. Further, what's your age? PC is pretty rare among young guys under 50, and the younger you are the less likely your elevated PSA is caused by cancer.

Posts.Title: Odds of PCa on elevated PSAs

Posts.Content: UCLA is a top flight academic medical center, if the husband is considering treatment for PC , that's the kind of place he needs to be. Radical prostatectomy is a very technically challenging surgery, you want a surgeon very experienced. You probably can't go wrong with any of the surgeons at UCLA, but you probably don't want to meet the doctor at the very top of the hill there. Quality institutions sometimes reserve the most difficult and challenging surgeries for their top guy. If you meet him, it means you're in worse shape.

Posts.Title: Newbie Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic My takeaway message is that you are treating only the identified lesions but making a risky bet that there are no others. That's clearly the problem with focal therapy, but one which improved imaging and more research into biological markers for disease will address over time. Proving the efficacy of FT is another problem. Giving FT to patients with medium to high risk disease could mean missing the boat as far as a cure for them, particularly as treating the whole prostate is proven effective. Giving FT to low risk patients might not prove a thing, even if its successful- as it may be an indolent disease not in need of being cured.

Posts.Title: Can Focal Therapy Replace Radical Therapy for Prostate Cancer? Against Focal Therapy

Posts.Content: UCLA is a top flight academic medical center, if the husband is considering treatment for PC , that's the kind of place he needs to be. Radical prostatectomy is a very technically challenging surgery, you want a surgeon very experienced. You probably can't go wrong with any of the surgeons at UCLA, but you probably don't want to meet the doctor at the very top of the hill there. Quality institutions sometimes reserve the most difficult and challenging surgeries for their top guy. If you meet him, it means you're in worse shape.

Posts.Title: Newbie Question

Posts.Content: An enlarged prostate definitely increases PSA, and yours is moderately elevated for a man of your age, so it isn't anything to be alarmed about. The key in active surveillance is that you definitely should be planning on another biopsy. TRUS biopsy does miss hot spots from time to time, repeat biopsies can usually catch them which might change your treatment plan.

Posts.Title: Active Survelliance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mainer Can anyone say why he should consider radiation? ( Radiation equipment and protocols have improved over the years, and they are more able to target the prostate with the beams. However, both radiation and surgery have similar side effects profiles, the difference is that you get the side effects up front with surgery and pay them more later with radiation. Since your husband is so young, the common wisdom is that surgery is usually more recommended. Older guys and guys in bad health- comorbidities- are recommended for radiation as they don't have as long to live to get all of the delayed action side effects.

Posts.Title: Great Yearly Follow Up Results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mags1310 I have searched through the internet trying to educate myself the best I can. I am requesting a copy of my husband's cat scan from the Dr because we never received a copy and the Dr had told me that it had showed a "misshapen bladder with a cyst/tumor in it". When I asked the size of the cyst/tumor he held up his hand and showed me a "grape" size. I think my question is how do they not know that this is prostate cancer that has spread to the bladder? . The bladder cyst doesn't sound like prostate cancer. PC usually doesn't metastasize to the bladder, usually goes to the bones. Further, the description the doctor had of it, a tumor that large would likely produce a lot more of an elevated PSA.

Posts.Title: Lots of research but still have questions

Posts.Content: A PSA in the 9's doesn't necessarily mean that the cancer will come back. PSA isn't cancer specific, prostrate infections and other factors can cause PSA to rise. Plenty of people who smoke and drink can live a lot longer than 68. Most people who smoke don't die of lung cancer, most people who drink don't die of cirrhosis. If you are sick now with severe heart disease or COPD, that's a factor in considering your course of treatment. But because you "might" get something else real deadly real quickly?
Posts.Title: PSA in the 9's G6 ... more cancer later?

Posts.Content: Active Surveillance and deferring treatment is certainly a possibility in your situation. But the key is to still follow up, with PSA testing and additional biopsies. Biopsies sometimes do miss "hot spots" in the prostate with higher grade cancer. We know that because when men have radical prostatectomies they ship the organ to the pathology lab and a sizable percentage come back with Gleason Upgrades. Having repeated biopsies reduces the chances that hot spots will be missed. Prostate cancer generally moves pretty slowly, and you have a low PSA and a well differentiated Gleason grade, there is no reason to panic yet.

Posts.Title: Just turned 38 and my prostate issues not going away is this indicative of PC?

Posts.Content: Not necessarily. The doctor can order an MRI to zone in on your prostate. They can also do genomic testing, which can determine your level of risk. Another alternative that they might consider is a "saturation" biopsy, where they take like 3 dozen cores.

Posts.Title: 2nd PSA still high after no cancer found in biopsy

Posts.Content: There are medications out there like proscar which can shrink the prostate without surgery. Ask the doctor what the medical options are. Urologists are surgeons by trade, and have a natural bias toward the scalpel. If you can handle it through medication, you won't be missing work and it would less expensive, as well as avoiding the pain of surgery.

Posts.Title: Lots of research but still have questions

Posts.Content: There are other treatments for BPH. Medications like Proscar, as well as surgeries or PAE. The problem is that you are already receiving brachytherapy, a doctor would have to tell you whether or not you can "switch" at this point in time. The radiation changes your prostate, and it might not react the same way. If Flomax is otherwise effective, a lot to be said for using an antidepressant for the meantime anyhow.

Posts.Title: New Here, seeking guidance, father recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Yes, there is hope. PSA scores of 4000 are not unheard of, and are certainly consistent with extensive stage IV disease. PSA is measure in "ng"'s which are billionths of a gram, very small amounts. The good news is that androgen deprivation therapy can be very effective in keeping the disease under control for an indefinite period of time. The stories and the searchable "yana now" website includes stories of men who have continued to live for 10 or more years with stage 4 disease, and new therapies are being devised all the time. Your father stands a very good chance of being around for many more years

Posts.Title: Dad with metastatic prostate cancer, is there hope?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RAD1964 He has not been scheduled for a bone scan or any other follow-up test, including genetic, as his urologist does not think it necessary (his words). This puzzles me, as I have since learned that scans and genetic tests are imperative. My bottom line question is: how much time do we have to make a decision on treatment? Any thoughts you can share with me about time frames would be most appreciated. Thanks so much, CPG Due to fact that your husband's PSA score is only moderately elevated and the biopsy shows that he is an intermediate risk, the urologist probably thinks a bone scan is pointless. The husband's numbers make it very unlikely that there are metastases and even less likely that any could be detected by the test. PC is most usually slow growing. Usually the fastest they will operate on is 8 weeks after the biopsy- waiting for the prostate to settle down after that abuse. A Gleason score of 7 usually means treatment, especially for a such a young man. But I think you definitely have time to get additional opinions and look to make a decision several months down the line. If you decide on AS, you can always change your mind you know

Posts.Title: Introducing myself and some questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I have a question. Radiation is suppose to kill the cancer cells, because they are by nature weaker cells, and spare the healthy cells. What stops the radiate prostate from continuing to produce cancer cells? In radiation treatment for prostate cancer, the whole prostate is treated- not just the tumor cells. The goal of the radiologists is to target the treatment just on that organ, and to avoid having it hit other organs and structures nearby.

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jgs3584 Here is what I have gotten from my mother. - His last reading (the one that prompted the biopsy) showed a PSA level of 6.5 and a clinical stage of T1c - The final diagnosis (pre-radiation treatment) was as follows. This is taken directly from the diagnostic sheet. A. Prostate, Right Lateral Apex, Core Biopsy - Adenocarcinoma of the Prostate, Gleason Score 4+3=7, involving one of one core (90%, 12MM) - Intraductal Spread of Invasive Carcinoma "intraductal" carcinoma is a bit more difficult of a problem than the usual kinds of PC. Being at a top flight academic medical center is a positivity as they've see it before, as opposed to smaller, community hospital or limited practices. Personally, I have a lot of confidence in UPMC, but by all means seek a second opinion. Sounds like he has co-morbidities affecting him as well as pc.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor - I can have the biopsy done on Monday IF I do it without the Propofol - Or I can wait for the urologist/nurse anesthesiologist review the chest X-ray and EKG on Monday the 30th and have the biopsy later in the week I did not find the biopsy to be a hard procedure at all. It isn't a very long procedure, they don't have mirrors in the room so you can't see them doing it, and I had it 3 times no problem and I turned down the valium. Getting serious anesthesia does increase the risk, they don't want you getting a bad reaction. If I were you, I'd think about just getting it done. Will they give you a valium instead of propofol without this special screening?

Posts.Title: Joining the club

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo According to the NY Times article (below), Robert Guillaume battled Prostate Cancer for 25 years.. Does anyone have any additional details on his battle? Living until 89, even without PCa, is nothing to sneeze over! By itself, this isn't that remarkable. I know a gentleman who was diagnosed 15 years ago, is now 83, and has done no treatment as he cancelled his appointment at the last moment. PSA has risen from 6 to 30, but he's still feeling fine. Many cases of prostate cancer are pretty slow moving.

Posts.Title: Prostate Drs Chicago Area

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Scott Howard I go to the bathroom mostly one time a night but sometimes twice. I have noticed that I go more often lately and it is more urgent. The big jump in PSA is what really concerns me. I have read that prostatitis could elevate the PSA so I have my fingers crossed. Anyway thanks for letting me air my concerns. After reading many posts I see there are many knowledgeable and caring people on this forum. Oh, I have a very caring and helpful wife to help me through anything that comes our way. She tells me not to get to worried until we get more information. Scott It may seem counterintuitive but the fact that you have prostate symptoms is actually a good omen that the rise in PSA scores is caused by prostatitis or BPH instead of cancer. Most prostate cancers don't cause symptoms until later, and prostatitis is perfectly capable of raising your PSA score. Try not to worry about it, there is a good chance that you don't have PC at all, and if you were to have it, there is an excellent chance you'll have a curative case.

Posts.Title: First post, elevated PSA reading today

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RAD1964 He has not been scheduled for a bone scan or any other follow-up test, including genetic, as his urologist does not think it necessary (his words). This puzzles me, as I have since learned that scans and genetic tests are imperative. My bottom line question is: how much time do we have to make a decision on treatment? Any thoughts you can share with me about time frames would be most appreciated. Thanks so much, CPG Due to fact that your husband's PSA score is only moderately elevated and the biopsy shows that he is an intermediate risk, the urologist probably thinks a bone scan is pointless. The husband's numbers make it very unlikely that there are metastases and even less likely that any could be detected by the test. PC is most usually slow growing. Usually the fastest they will operate on is 8 weeks after the biopsy- waiting for the prostate to settle down after that abuse. A Gleason score of 7 usually means treatment, especially for a such a young man. But I think you definitely have time to get additional opinions and look to make a decision several months down the line. If you decide on AS, you can always change your mind you know

Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind ASA is correct. You don't need a prescription for a PSA test or any other blood test..All you need is $60-80 bucks....Many medical labs have walk-in offices, they draw the blood and do the test right there..Takes about 6-12 hours for the results..They will email the result to you.. I was billed $140 from Quest for a PSA test a couple of years ago. My insurance didn't want to pay for it before I was diagnosed at age 57. As far as getting a PSA test for a 28 year old, I'm not sure how useful it would be. The OP should know that the PSA test is not specific to Prostate Cancer, and for someone as young as her son, an elevated score is a lot more likely to indicate prostatitis or other infection, which may or may not need to be treated, than it is PC.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer death

Posts.Content: The fact that you have having urinary symptoms is actually a positive sign in regards to your PSA. Prostate cancer that actually causes symptoms like yours would most likely create a lot more PSA, it sounds like an infection which also causes PSA to rise. Another biopsy is a smart idea, even if your PSA wasn't rising. TRUS biopsy misses a lot of cancer, repeated tests can catch a lot that might have been missed last time

Posts.Title: Scared to death.....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 I cannot believe that the PRIMARY treatment for prostate cancer is radiation at 58%. Although the date of the article was 2/19/15, the period studied was 2004-2007. The use of robotic surgery in the last 8 years -- AFTER this study was completed in 2007 -- has exploded in popularity. I would be interested in more up-to-date stats which, I feel certain, will show robotic surgery as the most utilized primary treatment now. The survey statistics were for all pc patients. A large number of patients are older or suffer from comorbidities who aren't recommended for surgery. Further, a good proportion of patients already have cancer at diagnosis which has spread and surgery isn't curative and usually not recommended. If there was a breakdown of stats and just those patients who were 65 or under and there was no likely spread of disease, they would be different.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer death

Posts.Content: ADT isn't considered to be a curative treatment for pc, and isn't usually given as a primary treatment for localized pc here in the United States because of that as well as its side effects. Reaistically your options would seem to be surgery, radiation or active surveillance. You might also want to have a 2nd opinion on your biopsy slides, to get the clearest picture you can on this.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by doubleH Hello forum, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer last October. In the biopsy, 2 of 12 cores were positive. The highest Gleason score was 3 + 3. Overall prostatic tissue involvement was 1.7%. The stage is T1c. Now the month before the biopsy, my PSA was 7.4. But in December, my PSA went up to 12.9. What could this mean? Does this mean that it is very likely that the biopsy in October missed a larger/more serious lesion? Anything is "possible" of course, and your doctor will be following up with you on this I'm sure. But it isn't time to panic at all. PSA isn't specific to prostate cancer for men who haven't been treated for it. It could have just as easily been caused by an infection or other irritation to the prostate- as sometimes happens when you have a prostate biopsy. 12 is a pretty high score, but not so high it couldn't be caused by something other than aggressive cancer.

Posts.Title: Low grade, high PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind ASA is correct. You don't need a prescription for a PSA test or any other blood test..All you need is $60-80 bucks....Many medical labs have walk-in offices, they draw the blood and do the test right there..Takes about 6-12 hours for the results..They will email the result to you.. I was billed $140 from Quest for a PSA test a couple of years ago. My insurance didn't want to pay for it before I was diagnosed at age 57. As far as getting a PSA test for a 28 year old, I'm not sure how useful it would be. The OP should know that the PSA test is not specific to Prostate Cancer, and for someone as young as her son, an elevated score is a lot more likely to indicate prostatitis or other infection, which may or may not need to be treated, than it is PC.

Posts.Title: Three year checkup

Posts.Content: Prostate Cancer is an extraordinarily rare disease for men of your age. If you did happen to have pc, tumors large enough to cause symptoms would create a lot more PSA than a reading of 2.5. There is no connection between the two. Hemorrhoids and edema in the legs are not typical symptoms of PC. I am not a doctor, but due to your age, its a lot more likely that your elevated PSA is due to prostatitis than cancer. The PSA is not a specific test for cancer, except for those men who have already had treatment for prostate cancer.

Prostate Cancer is quite rare for young guys and prostatitis is pretty common, I can see where your pcp would tilt a lot more in that direction. The worrying and anxiety is what's really killing you right now, maybe the doctor will give you some Miltowns when you go in tomorrow. You will not get a diagnosis of PC tomorrow, you know. Only a biopsy can make the diagnosis, if the urologist thinks PC is a possibility, you'll have to come back in a couple of weeks and it will probably be another week before the pathology report comes down. You have to get it together, this is going to take a little time.

Posts.Title: Adjuvent or Salvage Radiation?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SamPJ We have PSA test tomorrow. Is this stage IV? Is it curable? What are the next steps for us? Stage IV prostate cancer is not curable, but is definitely treatable with hormone therapy and new chemo agents coming out. Until there is a biopsy, its premature to say that it is prostate cancer. From your description, it doesn't sound that typical for PC. Usually prostate cancer presents as many multiple tumors, not a single large mass like your father has. In your dad's immediate future , a biopsy and bone scans are like right ahead. Ordinarily, stage IV Prostate cancer metastasizes to the bones.

Posts.Title: Do I really need a ultrasound guided prostate biopsy

Posts.Content: 4.7 is just modestly elevated for a man of your age. I wouldn't be terribly worried at all. The PSA test is not specific to prostate cancer, it goes higher as your prostate gets bigger as you get older. The normal prostate for a man who is 20, might be the size of a walnut, it reaches the size of a golf ball at age 40, a lemon at age 60, and a softball at age 80. you definitely want to follow up on this, it certainly might be a false negative, but more likely not.

Posts.Title: HELP!!! PLZ 38 year old with high PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic My takeaway message is that you are treating only the identified lesions but making a risky bet that there are no others. That's clearly the problem with focal therapy, but one which improved imaging and more research into biological markers for disease will address over time. Proving the efficacy of FT is another problem. Giving FT to patients with medium to high risk disease could mean missing the boat as far as a cure for them, particularly as treating the whole prostate is proven effective. Giving FT to low risk patients might not prove a thing, even if its successful- as it may be an indolent disease not in need of being cured.

Posts.Title: Penile implant

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Smasherie Does this mean that there is little hope? From everything I'm reading it sounds like it's going to come back and spread. If anyone has any advice or can give me more information on the realities of aggressive prostate cancer, I would appreciate it. I'm just at a loss. Thank you. There is plenty of hope. Gleason 9 cancer is definitely curable. The fact that they gave him a radical prostatectomy means the doctor believed the cancer is confined to the prostate and the fact that the lymph nodes are negative is a point of positivity. The main thing now is that they will probably line him up with radiation treatments as soon as he is healed from the surgery, and be aggressive with this. It is definitely higher risk, but it can also be cured.

Posts.Title: Gleason score of 9... what can we expect?

Posts.Content: 4.7 is just modestly elevated for a man of your age. I wouldn't be terribly worried at all. The PSA test is not specific to prostate cancer, it goes higher as your prostate gets bigger as you get older. The normal prostate for a man who is 20, might be the size of a walnut, it reaches the size of a golf ball at age 40, a lemon at age 60, and a softball at age 80. you definitely want to follow up on this, it certainly might be a false negative, but more likely not.

Posts.Title: New to cancer

Posts.Content: Both surgery and radiation treatments have similar sets of side effects. The main difference is that you get the side effects up front with surgical treatment and then you look to improve. With radiation, its the opposite, less side effects to start, but you pay for it later. As a result, older guys- in their 60's and 70's are more likely to go for the radiation- they'll miss out on some of the years of side effects as they'll be past their life expectancies when they come down. Even 10 is a very high PSA score, especially for someone who is only 37. Does he have chronic prostatitis or an enlarged prostate, they usually don't do screening PSA tests until a man reaches at least 40 and in many cases 50 or older. If he has surgery, his problems with that will disappear.

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: PSA stands for "prostate specific antigen", its a chemical that is released by only prostate cells. The test was originally designed for men who have already had prostatectomy. For those guys, the test should indicate a goose egg, they have no prostate, thus no prostate cells to create PSA. If they got a score , it means that cancerous prostate cells are creating PSA. The use of PSA for screening came afterwards. If you get a high or rapidly increasing score, the matter needs to be checked out further. BPH, prostatitis, other injury or trauma to the urinary tract can cause PSA scores to rise, sometimes dramatically. The idea of a screening PSA test result is to check it out if it looks out of sorts. Only a biopsy can definitlvely diagnose Prostate Cancer

Older guys and guys in bad health- comorbidities- are recommended for radiation as they don't have as long to live to get all of the delayed action side effects.

Posts.Title: Another new member here

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FredH J 1. I am in good health now so would be to my benefit to get it done now, rather than wait 2 or 3 years. 2. If in several years, I were upgraded to an 8, chances are they would push for seeds. With such a large prostate, they would require the drugs that shrink it which takes another 6 months or longer and make you feel terrible. 3. With this large prostate, cancer or not, I will probably require some sort of procedure to cure urine retention. I would really like both pro and con comments. What are your thoughts?? You got it a bit backwards on your first point. If you aren't in good health in several years, that would be a contraindication for surgery now. A decision for surgery is a bet that you will live long enough for the disease to advance to a point where it will harm you. One of top institutions in the country thinks it will take a good, long while for your PC to advance if it does, based on their recommendations. If you think you'll be in otherwise good health for the next 20 years or so, that would be the good cause to have the surgery now, not if you think you'll be sick.
Posts.Title: Gleason 6, Should I press for surgery?

Posts.Content: A PSA in the 9's doesn't necessarily mean that the cancer will come back. PSA isn't cancer specific, prostrate infections and other factors can cause PSA to rise. Plenty of people who smoke and drink can live a lot longer than 68. Most people who smoke don't die of lung cancer, most people who drink don't die of cirrhosis. If you are sick now with severe heart disease or COPD, that's a factor in considering your course of treatment. But because you "might" get something else real deadly real quickly?

Posts.Title: Prostate MRI on Friday

Posts.Content: Active Surveillance and deferring treatment is certainly a possibility in your situation. But the key is to still follow up, with PSA testing and additional biopsies. Biopsies sometimes do miss "hot spots" in the prostate with higher grade cancer. We know that because when men have radical prostatectomies they ship the organ to the pathology lab and a sizable percentage come back with Gleason Upgrades. Having repeated biopsies reduces the chances that hot spots will be missed. Prostate cancer generally moves pretty slowly, and you have a low PSA and a well differentiated Gleason grade, there is no reason to panic yet.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by cvictim Someone told me that most men with Prostate Cancer can live for years............. who are they kidding once it is metastasized you only have about 2-4 months give or take and I know personally of this. Once PC has metastasized, the disease is currently incurable. But its not true that you can't last for years, sometimes many years, depending on the aggressiveness of the disease and the effectiveness of the treatments. Some people do go downhill very quickly, but not everyone, and not even a majority.
Posts.Title: High PSA coming back...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jgs3584 Here is what I have gotten from my mother. - His last reading (the one that prompted the biopsy) showed a PSA level of 6.5 and a clinical stage of T1c - The final diagnosis (pre-radiation treatment) was as follows. This is taken directly from the diagnostic sheet. A. Prostate, Right Lateral Apex, Core Biopsy - Adenocarcinoma of the Prostate, Gleason Score 4+3=7, involving one of one core (90%, 12MM) - Intraductal Spread of Invasive Carcinoma "intraductal" carcinoma is a bit more difficult of a problem than the usual kinds of PC. Being at a top flight academic medical center is a positivity as they've see it before, as opposed to smaller, community hospital or limited practices. Personally, I have a lot of confidence in UPMC, but by all means seek a second opinion. Sounds like he has co-morbidities affecting him as well as pc.

Posts.Title: First Post - My 81 Year Old Father - Prostate Cancer - Treatment Failure

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Scott Howard I go to the bathroom mostly one time a night but sometimes twice. I have noticed that I go more often lately and it is more urgent. The big jump in PSA is what really concerns me. I have read that prostatitis could elevate the PSA so I have my fingers crossed. Anyway thanks for letting me air my concerns. After reading many posts I see there are many knowledgeable and caring people on this forum. Oh, I have a very caring and helpful wife to help me through anything that comes our way. She tells me not to get to worried until we get more information. Scott It may seem counterintuitive but the fact that you have prostate symptoms is actually a good omen that the rise in PSA scores is caused by prostatitis or BPH instead of cancer. Most prostate cancers don't cause symptoms until later, and prostatitis is perfectly capable of raising your PSA score. Try not to worry about it, there is a good chance that you don't have PC at all, and if you were to have it, there is an excellent chance you'll have a curative case.

It seems to me that they need more tests, an MRI and a confirmatory fusion biopsy, and genomics testing, before they can have have a decent guess as to whether AS is a good option for them. I think a man can make a tentative decision based on a TRUS biopsy. But returning for a 2nd biopsy or having other tests is pretty important.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ron_G For the life of me, I don't understand how medically trained doctors continue to do this. That's the way it was done at my primary care physician's office, and this gentleman's been around like forever. I think the reason is his procedures at the office. The assistant takes the blood pressure, the doctor comes in and examines the patient including DRE if appropriate, the doctors lets the assistant know what blood tests were needed, and they come back in for the blood draw. Doing the DRE *after* the blood draw would force a change in protocol.

Posts.Title: Age 33 - PSA 2.5 NERVOUS!!

Posts.Content: Prostate Cancer is an extraordinarily rare disease for men of your age. If you did happen to have pc, tumors large enough to cause symptoms would create a lot more PSA than a reading of 2.5. There is no connection between the two. Hemorrhoids and edema in the legs are not typical symptoms of PC. I am not a doctor, but due to your age, its a lot more likely that your elevated PSA is due to prostatitis than cancer. The PSA is not a specific test for cancer, except for those men who have already had treatment for prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by motoman1 Does this high PSA likely statistically mean cancer? What questions should I be asking?. It seems counterintuitive, but the fact that you've had urinary symptoms and have undergone testing, makes it less likely you have cancer. in spite of a highly elevated PSA score. With DRE's and other procedures you have as well as an infectionary situation, that could certainly be a reason for the PSA to rise to alarming levels. The only way prostate cancer can be diagnosed is with a biopsy. The doctor will probably recommend it.

Posts.Title: Joining the club

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 I cannot believe that the PRIMARY treatment for prostate cancer is radiation at 58%. Although the date of the article was 2/19/15, the period studied was 2004-2007. The use of robotic surgery in the last 8 years -- AFTER this study was completed in 2007 -- has exploded in popularity. I would be interested in more up-to-date stats which, I feel certain, will show robotic surgery as the most utilized primary treatment now. The survey statistics were for all pc patients. A large number of patients are older or suffer from comorbidities who aren't recommended for surgery. Further, a good proportion of patients already have cancer at diagnosis which has spread and surgery isn't curative and usually not recommended. If there was a breakdown of stats and just those patients who were 65 or under and there was no likely spread of disease, they would be different.
Posts.Title: Interesting Statistics on Prostate Cancer Treatment Options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by doubleH Hello forum, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer last October. In the biopsy, 2 of 12 cores were positive. The highest Gleason score was 3 + 3. Overall prostatic tissue involvement was 1.7%. The stage is T1c. Now the month before the biopsy, my PSA was 7.4. But in December, my PSA went up to 12.9. What could this mean? Does this mean that it is very likely that the biopsy in October missed a larger/more serious lesion? Anything is "possible" of course, and your doctor will be following up with you on this I'm sure. But it isn't time to panic at all. PSA isn't specific to prostate cancer for men who haven't been treated for it. It could have just as easily been caused by an infection or other irritation to the prostate- as sometimes happens when you have a prostate biopsy. 12 is a pretty high score, but not so high it couldn't be caused by something other than aggressive cancer.

Posts.Title: Age 33 - PSA 2.5 NERVOUS!!

Posts.Content: Prostate Cancer is an extraordinarily rare disease for men of your age. If you did happen to have pc, tumors large enough to cause symptoms would create a lot more PSA than a reading of 2.5. There is no connection between the two. Hemorrhoids and edema in the legs are not typical symptoms of PC. I am not a doctor, but due to your age, its a lot more likely that your elevated PSA is due to prostatitis than cancer. The PSA is not a specific test for cancer, except for those men who have already had treatment for prostate cancer.

With 5 positive cores, and your husband's young age, you'll probably want to go for a cure-radiation or surgery- anyhow if it is still localized. Since you already had one of the top pathologists look at it, it might not be necessary to have a 2nd opinion.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Smasherie Does this mean that there is little hope? From everything I'm reading it sounds like it's going to come back and spread. If anyone has any advice or can give me more information on the realities of aggressive prostate cancer, I would appreciate it. I'm just at a loss. Thank you. There is plenty of hope. Gleason 9 cancer is definitely curable. The fact that they gave him a radical prostatectomy means the doctor believed the cancer is confined to the prostate and the fact that the lymph nodes are negative is a point of positivity. The main thing now is that they will probably line him up with radiation treatments as soon as he is healed from the surgery, and be aggressive with this. It is definitely higher risk, but it can also be cured.

I am not an expert, but it is most important to be able to detect recurrent PCa as early as possible. Thus have the discussion about how to best monitor IDCP recurrence moving forward. If PSA is not valid, then hopefully there are other "biomarker" tests that can detect the presence of recurrent IDCP. My mother had lung cancer surgery maybe 15 years ago? Anyhoo, there is no biochemical marker for recurrence of her cancer, so I just had to drive her to the surgeon once a year to have a scanning done for like 5 years. I suppose its the same for a PC which doesn't produce PSA.

Posts.Title: Second Opinion on Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: If you have surgery, you'll be off work for at least a month to heal, but that's from the treatment not the disease. For Social Security disability checks in the United States, you'd have to be diagnosed with Stage 4 cancer to qualify on the basis of PCa. Unless it is advanced disease, prostate cancer isn't likely to be actually disabling- a lot of prominent people here in America have continued to work even with metastatic disease. Canada and/or Germany may have different rules on who qualifies for a disability check that America, but as far actual disability from PCa, you are still not there yet and hopefully won't be.

Posts.Title: Cans and Can'ts with PCa

Posts.Content: 4.7 is just modestly elevated for a man of your age. I wouldn't be terribly worried at all. The PSA test is not specific to prostate cancer, it goes higher as your prostate gets bigger as you get older. The normal prostate for a man who is 20, might be the size of a walnut, it reaches the size of a golf ball at age 40, a lemon at age 60, and a softball at age 80. you definitely want to follow up on this, it certainly might be a false negative, but more likely not.

Posts.Title: Maybe, maybe not? Whats up?

Posts.Content: Neither PSA nor testosterone cause PC. Testosterone is fuel for PC that you already have. PSA is not particular to prostate cancer, and in spite of its name- "prostate specific antigen", its really not even specific to the prostate as women have (low) PSA readings naturally too.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GMJJ CT scan will cost $1000. The hospital hasn't notified us cost of bone scan. In January, our costs will be substantially reduced. He wants to wait. What is your honest opinion? What would you do? You have to wait 6 weeks anyhow after a biopsy, before doing a radical prostatectomy. Six weeks from late October puts you in the middle of December- as the earliest possible date for surgery. Waiting until January doesn't seem crazy risky at all- the doctor said do something within 6 months, and this is substantially less than that.

Posts.Content: Scheduling for January is fine, if you are ready to commit to surgery. Of course, depending on the tests or other factors, you or the doctor can always back out or defer. But sooner is generally better. Even if you wanted to do it during December, might not even be possible. I'd think that a lot of urologists are taking off time for Christmas, and only coming in for folks who have their bladders pierced by the bow and arrow set they got for Xmas or other emergencies.

Posts.Title: Woo hoo- good PSA result

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by steve135 In talking with doctor about results the meds are some what masking the the PSA results. Does that mean keeping PSA at zero? Or does it mean they can't measure the real amount do to drugs? So is my PSA really .006 or something else that can't be seen through the drugs. This to make me mentally feel somethings working? You're PSA score is really .006, that's what the lab said a couple of times, no reason to doubt them. It seems like the treatment that you were given in 2017- Salvage RT and adjuvant ADT- is designed to hopefully cure you. ADT treatment definitely does suppress PSA scores. Once he takes you off of ADT, your PSA score will probably rise somewhat from its current levels. Not that high if you are cured, but somewhat. And when that happens, the hope is you won't be panicky about it.

Posts.Title: SBRT 5 year study released. Claimed "98% cure rate"

Posts.Content: It might not be prostate cancer at all. Elderly men your grandfather's age often have very large prostates, its an organ that grows with age. An enlarged prostate can increase someone's PSA score. People, particularly older people, often suffer from arthritis, rheumatism, or other afflictions that also cause bone pain

Posts.Content: My understanding is that they need to get the part which they are focusing on into the middle of the MRI machine. If its your head or shoulders, you'll definitely be in a tight situation for a claustrophobe. If you are tall, however and they are imaging you prostate, you'll be partly of the machine. I'm 6'1,and my head was half way out. If I was taller, my head might have been totally out.

Posts.Title: How bad is the MRI?

Posts.Content: The scans that your dad are having will determine if he has a curable case or not. If he does, then he'll want to do either surgery or radiation treatments, either of which are just about equally curative. Due to his young age, they'll probably recommend surgery, which has the advantage of allowing the pathologists to slice and dice the whole prostate and find out if there is something more aggressive in there. Unless dad has serious co-morbidities which give him a significantly shorter life expectancy than the usual 56 yo man, active surveillance isn't that much of a viable option in this case.

Posts.Content: You had a rapid growth in PSA score, which doesn't mean rapid growth in cancer. The fact that your PSA score fell sharply after its peak of 12, shows the 12 wasn't due to cancer. Maybe an MRI or other test might be in order, I'd listen to the doctor on that.

Posts.Title: Dad's PSA spike in less than 6 months

Posts.Content: At age 68 and Gleason 6 cancer, it isn't a medical emergency and active surveillance should be considered. The one caveat I would give you, is to make sure you follow up and probably have another biopsy in a year. Not so much to check for "progression", although that is part of it. But to check for hotter spots. A lot of understated biopsies are done, and you want to make sure you are a true Gleason 6,

Posts.Title: Interesting Article in Washington Post about PCA TReatment

Posts.Content: The scans that your dad are having will determine if he has a curable case or not. If he does, then he'll want to do either surgery or radiation treatments, either of which are just about equally curative. Due to his young age, they'll probably recommend surgery, which has the advantage of allowing the pathologists to slice and dice the whole prostate and find out if there is something more aggressive in there. Unless dad has serious co-morbidities which give him a significantly shorter life expectancy than the usual 56 yo man, active surveillance isn't that much of a viable option in this case.

Posts.Title: Probability?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by thenson 3. since cancer was confirmed with the December 20th biopsy and that about 75% of my prostate could be cancerous, does the risk of cancer metastasizing outside the prostate increase significantly with each month we delay surgery or treatment? You're reading that wrong. 75% of the cores taken during the biopsy had some cancer in them. The biopsy report also indicates the percentage of each positive core which is cancerous as well. The only way they can really know how large your prostate tumors are is to cut it out and slice and dice it. Prostate cancer is a slow mover, and your PSA is only modestly elevated. No one can say for sure how long you have to work, but you certainly would seem to have time to get a 2nd opinion and maybe see a radiation man for that possible treatment plan. Prostatectomy is one of the most technically challenging surgeries commonly done for surgeons-whether done robotically or open, you will definitely want to chat with the surgeon next week about his experience. You'll want someone with at least hundreds of these operations under their belt if not thousands.

Posts.Title: How to tell my seurgon that

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MK44 Hi all. I am going to share my story so far here, and ask if anyone else has experienced similar things (as a younger person or otherwise). Any advice would be appreciated. Earlier this week I called the surgery and was told that everything was normal, there would be no further action needed, and I could visit again in the future if there were any more problems. I asked for a print of the results, which I wanted to keep as a record. However my heart sunk a bit when I saw that PSA was 3.7, which I know to be fairly unusual for someone of my age. It seems the theoretical cut off is 4 for PSA, and my GP has acted in line with that. I have a background in healthcare and I recognised that the other tests were indeed quite normal. Obviously the worry is that my symptoms, which continue as of today, plus the PSA score, indicates an more serious unwanted problem. I know that my fathers PSA reached 7-8 just before he was diagnosed. Then again I also know that I am not a man of 66.... Anyone else have experience approaching doctors in this sort of situation? I had a few episodes of prostatitis as a youngun and it isn't pleasant. You should note a few things. The PSA test is not particular to cancer, infections, enlarged prostates can cause an elevated score too. PC is exceedingly rare among guys of your age. Further, prostate cancer in its early stage is almost always completely asymptomatic. Your PSA score is elevated, but only modestly. A prostate tumor big enough to actually cause symptoms would almost certainly create a lot more PSA than a 3.7 reading would indicate. I think the doctors are giving you very reasonable advice

Doctor said based on my age (73) and PSA numbers, I have a 12% change of getting prostate cancer. She tried to explain the math involved in coming up with that number but I could not follow. I guess I'm OK for now but those atypical cells still concern me. Your numbers look good, 4.2 PSA isn't even considered elevated for a man of your age, and a healthy enough Free PSA score. Prostate biopsies are the bread and butter for those in the urology field, if they thought they were justified in recommending one, they would. You are seeing a doctor at a top academic medical center, it sounds to me like you are being treated fine

Posts.Title: Fusion Biopsy Fear (Big Baby?)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by John1966 I My first thought is to seek a biopsy ASAP and then treat aggressively. Is there a downside to haveing a biopsy? Or more than one over a course of time? And does all treatment lead to impotence? . There sure are downsides to having a biopsy, there is definitely a possibility of a serious infection and some patients really find them painful ( although I didn't) PSA scores are not specific to prostate cancer, prostatitis or other irritation to the urinary tract can cause the score to rise as well. The conservative approach of doing another PSA test a couple of months down the line has a lot to be said for it. That being said, with a PSA score over 4, if you have good insurance, you should be able to find a urologist to do the biopsy. But a lot of people have health anxiety, and a biopsy might actually fuel that. False negatives are possible, additional tests, worrying about the pathology reports. If you really have health anxiety, a biopsy could make it worse

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ketoman What significance would you place on this 22% DECREASE? Many thanks Cancer isn't the only reason why PSA goes up or down, even in patients that have cancer. Urinary infections, BPH, various kinds of trauma can occur that can affect the PSA reading. The only time that a PSA score is solely caused by cancer is when the patient has had definitive treatment for PC.

Posts.Title: Young Guy with Strange Symptoms and Diagnosis - Should I do a Biopsy?

Posts.Content: PSA is not a cancer specific test for those men who have not undergone treatment for prostate cancer. For men who have had their prostates irradiated or removed, only cancer can cause a rise in the score. But for others, its just a sign of possible sign of something which just needs to be explored. If the cipro doesn't work, the surgeon will probably recommend a biopsy which is the only way to diagnose PC.

Posts.Title: Fusion Biopsy Fear (Big Baby?)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MK44 Hi all. I am going to share my story so far here, and ask if anyone else has experienced similar things (as a younger person or otherwise). Any advice would be appreciated. Earlier this week I called the surgery and was told that everything was normal, there would be no further action needed, and I could visit again in the future if there were any more problems. I asked for a print of the results, which I wanted to keep as a record. However my heart sunk a bit when I saw that PSA was 3.7, which I know to be fairly unusual for someone of my age. It seems the theoretical cut off is 4 for PSA, and my GP has acted in line with that. I have a background in healthcare and I recognised that the other tests were indeed quite normal. Obviously the worry is that my symptoms, which continue as of today, plus the PSA score, indicates an more serious unwanted problem. I know that my fathers PSA reached 7-8 just before he was diagnosed. Then again I also know that I am not a man of 66.... Anyone else have experience approaching doctors in this sort of situation? I had a few episodes of prostatitis as a youngun and it isn't pleasant. You should note a few things. The PSA test is not particular to cancer, infections, enlarged prostates can cause an elevated score too. PC is exceedingly rare among guys of your age. Further, prostate cancer in its early stage is almost always completely asymptomatic. Your PSA score is elevated, but only modestly. A prostate tumor big enough to actually cause symptoms would almost certainly create a lot more PSA than a 3.7 reading would indicate. I think the doctors are giving you very reasonable advice

Posts.Title: Fusion Biopsy Fear (Big Baby?)

Posts.Content: The problem with testosterone treatments for prostate cancer patients is the idea that testosterone feeds the cancer. Theoretically, if all of your cancer is removed with the surgery, it shouldn't be a problem. But they really can't be that certain. Suppose just a small amount of cancer escaped the prostate. It might stay indolent indefinitely for the rest of your life and not be a problem. But if fed testosterone, it might grow and cause problems perhaps even enough to kill you dead. In the future, I think that research will provide more info on this, but right now, its better to be safe.

Posts.Title: Rapid Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by John1966 I My first thought is to seek a biopsy ASAP and then treat aggressively. Is there a downside to haveing a biopsy? Or more than one over a course of time? And does all treatment lead to impotence? . There sure are downsides to having a biopsy, there is definitely a possibility of a serious infection and some patients really find them painful ( although I didn't) PSA scores are not specific to prostate cancer, prostatitis or other irritation to the urinary tract can cause the score to rise as well. The conservative approach of doing another PSA test a couple of months down the line has a lot to be said for it. That being said, with a PSA score over 4, if you have good insurance, you should be able to find a urologist to do the biopsy. But a lot of people have health anxiety, and a biopsy might actually fuel that. False negatives are possible, additional tests, worrying about the pathology reports. If you really have health anxiety, a biopsy could make it worse

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garrjim I have also researched a new procedure by Dr. Sperling which treatment is done by laser. (which looks very promising). The established prostate protocols-radiation and surgery- involve treating the whole prostate, protocols like Dr. Sperling's are pretty new and not entirely proven. The problem with focal treatment is the problem with imaging. Very difficult to really get a clear pics that will distinguish diseased from healthy parts of the prostate. There isn't usually just 1 prostate tumor, but a dozen or more small ones is typical. Focal treatment might work, but it isn't a proven treatment plan yet

Posts.Title: PCa and dairy.

Posts.Content: Prostatitis is common enough, and usually very self-limited often resolving itself on its own. Sometimes doctors will give you an antibiotic for it, it can be caused by gonorrhea or chlamydia, which can respond to this. It isn't a sign of cancer, its most often just an annoyance rather than a real cause of worry.

Posts.Title: "Inflamed" prostate - should I be worried?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ontheroad See if you can get any reaction to the insurance status of folks here in the USA, struggling with stage 4 cancer, and currently using the ACA as their only source of insurance. People with stage 4 cancer are presumptively eligible for social security disability payments, and can also qualify for medicaid "automatically" if they've been disabled for more than 2 years provided they are otherwise eligible. There is a hole in coverage here, but the hole isn't as large as some people might think.

Posts.Title: Zero Cancer - An end to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe I know this question has been asked thousand times but are any of you taking a supplement that you think is helping with your prostate. Like saw palmetto, etc. Now if you do a search you will find a thread where I was taking a pomegranate pill but later read that that could rise the PSA number so I stopped. Now, I have not been diagnosed with PC yet but I probably have it based on a biopsy that I had which found atypical cell and a PSA of 5.9. I will be 74 in June. So are there any magic pills out there. The problem with taking supplements is they might really change your PSA scores without changing any underlying disease, making these tests less useful to the physician. It could be like taking the "check engine" light bulb out of your dashboard on your car. Not really unhealthful per se, but it could possibly delay an early warning to a bad report. If you do decide to take a supplement, at least make a record and tell your doctor exactly what you are doing on that end.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Recurrence - PSA rising after Prostate Surgery - next steps?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lordsnot Several weeks ago I went through a dreadful couple of weeks where I was suffering from tenesmus combine with persistent urge to pee as well. I assumed it was a UC flare (I have Ulcerative Colitis), I started smoking cigarettes again and the symptoms went away in two days. Less than a week after the symptoms subsided I had a blood draw. PSA was 14.4!!! I am scared $hitless and my follow up with my Dr isnt for another two weeks (he's away for vacation). Could I have prostatitis? Hope you're feeling better. But remember that any kind of traumatic event to your lower regions can cause a rise in the PSA score. Riding a bicycle,sexual relations, biopsies and other medical procedures, as well as infections can cause a rise. The non-urinary ailments you have dealt with seem to be the most like reason for your spike instead of prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: 38 Years old with High PSA

Posts.Content: Your brother should definitely seek a 2nd opinion on this. There are treatments other than ADT for metastatic PC, including Provenge which is an immunological treatment. There are also questions about whether to start ADT quickly, or delay it, have continuous hormone suppression or intermittent. The relative aggressiveness of the cancer as determined by the biopsy, as well as the physician's own philosophy and judgment are factors, hearing someone else's opinion on this would seem pretty wise.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic So what happens to men with an initial negative biopsy? Statistically speaking, that is. My first biopsy was positive. However, I fully expected the result to be negative. What can I say, I'm a cup half full kind of guy. I don't think I would have gone back to the urologist. I was first referred to the urologist at age 51, several years before that because my PSA was at 3 after an increase. The doctor did not do a biopsy, but instead rescheduled me for 6 months and a new PSA test. After I got the PSA results and saw they were a 2, I cancelled the urology appointment. I didn't have a problem getting a biopsy, I am cool with a certain amount of testing, I wouldn't have continued on without a positive test result.

Posts.Title: PSA levels went lower with trial drug

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Internship41 Will salvage RT at some point save his life? Can he live until at least 75 or does he has ony 5 y or so? Its really uncertain at this point in time whether he will even need salvage RT, PSA scores are fluctuating for him. But Salvage RT is prescribed to cure, to mop up after RP, and effect a permanent cure. If this treatment is prescribed for him, that will be the realistic goal, and you have to think positive, the doctors presumably know what they are doing. But even if salvage RT is prescribed and doesn't work, doesn't mean that he doesn't have many more years. There are ways to manage Stage 4 PC that can extend people's lives for many years. Particularly in your father's case, where his PSA looks like its really rising slowly, it would seem more likely that if he dies within 5 years or 15, it will be from something other than PC.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JulesM Anyone else out there have anything similar? What's your thoughts? Thanks sooo much It makes sense what your doctor is saying. His PSA level is only moderately elevated, and the pathology report on his biopsy shows only an intermediate risk and not any atypical kinds of prostate cancer. With that profile of prostate cancer, there is really very little chance of anything appearing on a bone scan or pet scan. A cancer big enough to cause pain and to have metastasized, would almost undoubtably create a lot more PSA.

Posts.Title: IMRT vs Proton

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne I am still wondering what is to be done in case of a negative biopsy, especially w/ respect to prostatitis. When I was in my late 30's, early 40's, I had burning urination and I was given antibiotics like Proloprim, and penicillin. I don't know if it worked, but my symptoms went away. Some people suffer more, and some people have asymptomatic prostatitis as well. If your biopsy is negative, that's good. But unless they can push your PSA score down with antibiotics, they will be really interested in doing another biopsy or at least an MRI, even with a negative biopsy. A TRUS biopsy has maybe a 30% chance of a false negative.
