Posts.Title: PSA Test Result analysis (6 weeks post-surgery)?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Firemedic54 My Urologist has suggested Davinci surgery as really the only option. I understand the Gleason of 6 is a favorable dx. I also believe a 3+3 is in my favor. How do they come up with the 3+3 as opposed to a 4+2?. Prostate cancer cells are graded from 1 to 5, depending on how irregular and aggressive they seem to the pathologist. 3+3 means that the 1st and 2nd most common patterns of cancer cells were both graded as "3"'s. 3 is effectively the lowest grade that they assign in the modern era, so 3+3 would indicate a lower risk diagnosis. I don't think that 4+2 is a diagnosis that's given by many doctors, but "4" indicates a moderately aggressive disease with at least some of the cells in your prostate and would make it a significantly risker disease situation. You should definitely get a second opinion on your diagnosis as well as the pathology report. Urologists are surgeons by trade, they are naturally more inclined to believe in and recommend surgery.

Posts.Title: Recommendations for RALP in the Chicago area

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Internship41 Will salvage RT at some point save his life? Can he live until at least 75 or does he has ony 5 y or so? Its really uncertain at this point in time whether he will even need salvage RT, PSA scores are fluctuating for him. But Salvage RT is prescribed to cure, to mop up after RP, and effect a permanent cure. If this treatment is prescribed for him, that will be the realistic goal, and you have to think positive, the doctors presumably know what they are doing. But even if salvage RT is prescribed and doesn't work, doesn't mean that he doesn't have many more years. There are ways to manage Stage 4 PC that can extend people's lives for many years. Particularly in your father's case, where his PSA looks like its really rising slowly, it would seem more likely that if he dies within 5 years or 15, it will be from something other than PC.

Posts.Title: Nearing the end of active surveillance

Posts.Content: Sounds like an excessive delay for biopsy results. The first biopsy I had, it took 2 weeks but they shipped off the samples to a path lab in Irving Texas (from Pittsburgh). It took less than a week for my 2 subsequent biopsies as the pathology lab was in the same building as the test. What usually happens in these cases is that if it comes back positive, you can get bone scans and sometimes other tests to stage the cancer. That determines your options. It may seem counterintuitive, but the fact you have urinary symptoms is actually positive. Cancers are usually asymptomatic, and a cancer that did cause the symptoms you report would likely create a lot more PSA as well. Infections and BPH can also increase PSA scores.

Posts.Title: Pathology Report seems OK or maybe not so OK

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Firemedic54 My Urologist has suggested Davinci surgery as really the only option. I understand the Gleason of 6 is a favorable dx. I also believe a 3+3 is in my favor. How do they come up with the 3+3 as opposed to a 4+2?. Prostate cancer cells are graded from 1 to 5, depending on how irregular and aggressive they seem to the pathologist. 3+3 means that the 1st and 2nd most common patterns of cancer cells were both graded as "3"'s. 3 is effectively the lowest grade that they assign in the modern era, so 3+3 would indicate a lower risk diagnosis. I don't think that 4+2 is a diagnosis that's given by many doctors, but "4" indicates a moderately aggressive disease with at least some of the cells in your prostate and would make it a significantly risker disease situation. You should definitely get a second opinion on your diagnosis as well as the pathology report. Urologists are surgeons by trade, they are naturally more inclined to believe in and recommend surgery.

Posts.Title: Biopsy with or without anaesthesia?

Posts.Content: This is a matter of dispute among the learned scholars of the urology profession- whether to commence hormone treatments immediately or how long to wait. Dr. Patrick Walsh covers this dispute in his book, and suggests that some cancers aren't growing that fast, and that results are no worse among patients who wait for ADT than those who get it immediately. There are other doctors that apparently disagree with Walsh on this. "So far, there has been no convincing scientific evidence to prove that early hormonal therapy prolongs life. In chapter 10, we talked about the Johns Hopkins study that followed men who had an elevated PSA level after radical prostatectomy. We found that, on average, it took eight years for these men to develop metastases in the bones. We also developed a means of predicting when metastases may show up, using the Gleason score on the radical prostatectomy specimen (whether it was more or less than , the time after radical prostatectomy when the PSA level first increased (whether it was more or less than two years), and how long it took for the PSA level to double (whether it was more or less than ten months). Using this information, a man can quickly determine his risk of developing metastatic disease. In one of the most common scenarios, a man with Gleason 7 disease who developed a PSA level elevation more than two years after surgery who had a PSA doubling time longer than ten months had an 82 percent likelihood of being metastasis-free at seven years. On the other hand, if the PSA had gone up within the first two years and the PSA doubling time was less than ten months, then the likelihood of freedom from metastatic disease at seven years would be only 15 percent. This information can tell men how long it will be before they actually need hormones - if they ever do. Why should they subject themselves to these serious side effects if they don't have to, and if there is no convincing scientific reason to do so? Whether a man is treated with hormonal therapy immediately, as soon as the diagnosis of advanced disease is made, or his doctor waits until the man has signs of progression and then begins treatment, we believe - and study after study proves-that survival is exactly the same. There is no compelling evidence that any kind of hormonal therapy works better earlier than later, when a man begins experiencing symptoms such as urinary obstruction or has a positive bane scan. And yet, it's highly unlikely that a man who is symptom-free (also called asymptomatic) is going to feel any better once he has been deprived of his normal hormones. Again, the cancer cells that ultimately prove fatal in prostate cancer are the hormone-insensitive cells. They keep right on growing, unaffected by hormonal therapy. To these cells, whether hormonal therapy comes earlier or later does not matter. For an asymptomatic man, early hormonal therapy means going from feeling fine and normal to experiencing hot flashes; loss of libido and the ability to have an erection; weight gain; changes in muscle mass, skin, and hair growth; and the subtle changes in personality that accompany the loss of male hormones. As we discussed earlier, the long-term effects of hormonal therapy can include osteoporosis, loss of bone density, leaving bones more brittle and easy to break and decreases in mental acuity. What's the point of going through this early when, ultimately, you could achieve exactly the same benefit if you wait to start hormonal therapy until there is evidence of disease progression? The idea of early hormonal therapy appeals to many men because it's doing something rather than nothing. Many doctors, too, promote a proactive approach, telling their patients that this will delay progression of the disease. Actually, it takes a lot of time for a doctor to convince a man not to start early hormonal therapy - and unfortunately, many doctors don't have very much time to spend with their patients. If you want to attack the cancer aggressively, don't pin all your hopes on hormones. Instead, read the section below on non hormonal approaches, and consider enrolling yourself in a clinical trial - there are many - aimed at killing the cancer cells that hormonal therapy can't touch".

Posts.Title: Immediate or delayed ADT

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KarlEmagne I am still wondering what is to be done in case of a negative biopsy, especially w/ respect to prostatitis. When I was in my late 30's, early 40's, I had burning urination and I was given antibiotics like Proloprim, and penicillin. I don't know if it worked, but my symptoms went away. Some people suffer more, and some people have asymptomatic prostatitis as well. If your biopsy is negative, that's good. But unless they can push your PSA score down with antibiotics, they will be really interested in doing another biopsy or at least an MRI, even with a negative biopsy. A TRUS biopsy has maybe a 30% chance of a false negative.

Posts.Title: Early Detection/Ben Stiller

Posts.Content: This is a matter of dispute among the learned scholars of the urology profession- whether to commence hormone treatments immediately or how long to wait. Dr. Patrick Walsh covers this dispute in his book, and suggests that some cancers aren't growing that fast, and that results are no worse among patients who wait for ADT than those who get it immediately. There are other doctors that apparently disagree with Walsh on this. "So far, there has been no convincing scientific evidence to prove that early hormonal therapy prolongs life. In chapter 10, we talked about the Johns Hopkins study that followed men who had an elevated PSA level after radical prostatectomy. We found that, on average, it took eight years for these men to develop metastases in the bones. We also developed a means of predicting when metastases may show up, using the Gleason score on the radical prostatectomy specimen (whether it was more or less than , the time after radical prostatectomy when the PSA level first increased (whether it was more or less than two years), and how long it took for the PSA level to double (whether it was more or less than ten months). Using this information, a man can quickly determine his risk of developing metastatic disease. In one of the most common scenarios, a man with Gleason 7 disease who developed a PSA level elevation more than two years after surgery who had a PSA doubling time longer than ten months had an 82 percent likelihood of being metastasis-free at seven years. On the other hand, if the PSA had gone up within the first two years and the PSA doubling time was less than ten months, then the likelihood of freedom from metastatic disease at seven years would be only 15 percent. This information can tell men how long it will be before they actually need hormones - if they ever do. Why should they subject themselves to these serious side effects if they don't have to, and if there is no convincing scientific reason to do so? Whether a man is treated with hormonal therapy immediately, as soon as the diagnosis of advanced disease is made, or his doctor waits until the man has signs of progression and then begins treatment, we believe - and study after study proves-that survival is exactly the same. There is no compelling evidence that any kind of hormonal therapy works better earlier than later, when a man begins experiencing symptoms such as urinary obstruction or has a positive bane scan. And yet, it's highly unlikely that a man who is symptom-free (also called asymptomatic) is going to feel any better once he has been deprived of his normal hormones. Again, the cancer cells that ultimately prove fatal in prostate cancer are the hormone-insensitive cells. They keep right on growing, unaffected by hormonal therapy. To these cells, whether hormonal therapy comes earlier or later does not matter. For an asymptomatic man, early hormonal therapy means going from feeling fine and normal to experiencing hot flashes; loss of libido and the ability to have an erection; weight gain; changes in muscle mass, skin, and hair growth; and the subtle changes in personality that accompany the loss of male hormones. As we discussed earlier, the long-term effects of hormonal therapy can include osteoporosis, loss of bone density, leaving bones more brittle and easy to break and decreases in mental acuity. What's the point of going through this early when, ultimately, you could achieve exactly the same benefit if you wait to start hormonal therapy until there is evidence of disease progression? The idea of early hormonal therapy appeals to many men because it's doing something rather than nothing. Many doctors, too, promote a proactive approach, telling their patients that this will delay progression of the disease. Actually, it takes a lot of time for a doctor to convince a man not to start early hormonal therapy - and unfortunately, many doctors don't have very much time to spend with their patients. If you want to attack the cancer aggressively, don't pin all your hopes on hormones. Instead, read the section below on non hormonal approaches, and consider enrolling yourself in a clinical trial - there are many - aimed at killing the cancer cells that hormonal therapy can't touch".

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lostcause My doctors have told me my prostate cancer has spread to my bones. Specifically my sternum, ribs, lower lumbar region and left femur. They refuse to tell me how grim my prognosis is. Instead I get this "I've had many patients live for years even though it has spread to their bones". Are the just giving me BS. You can not only live for many years, you can many productive years in spite of having metastatic prostate cancer. The man who played Briscoe on the Law and Order program did almost his entire stint on that program with stage 4 pc. Most people respond to effective treatments for the disease, the only question is how long will the treatments be effective. [REFERENCE TO ANOTHER PC FORUM DELETED PER FORUM RULES] IN PARAPHRASE TO WHAT WAS SAID -- There are a lot of people that are living with pc for very long periods of time
